SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.

This bill is about the right of all Australians to speak freely and inform others of their political and electoral choices. It repeals section 329A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, under which it is an offence to advocate a method of voting which is in fact legal, formal and legitimate.
Section 329A was controversial when it was introduced in December 1992 and has become more so with each subsequent election.

In 1996 we had the spectacle of Albert Langer being imprisoned for 10 weeks for contempt of court because he refused to stop advocating a perfectly legal form of voting. Amnesty International described him as Australia's first prisoner of conscience for over 20 years. The now Prime Minister Mr Howard described s.329A as a `silly law' and `an unacceptable infringement of the right to free speech' (letter to Mr Ken Partridge, Launceston, 28 February 1996).
I promised during the election campaign that one of my first actions, if elected, would be a move to repeal this law. This bill fulfils that commitment.
I want to emphasise that my concern is with free speech. I am not supporting or endorsing the form of optional preferential voting that is permitted under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.

The Greens believe that proportional representation is the fairest and most democratic voting system, and that the national parliament should follow Tasmania and the ACT, not to mention most European countries and New Zealand, by adopting it. Under the current system of voting for the House of Representatives, half the electorate will end up with a member that they didn't vote for or to whom they are actively opposed. Proportional representation with multi‐member electorates enables everyone to be represented by at least one member who reflects view similar to their own. I have already flagged that I will be proposing amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act to introduce proportional representation.
In the meantime, I urge senators to remove this impediment to free speech by repealing s.329A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Margetts) agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) for his incompetent and insensitive handling of his portfolio in the following areas:

(a) failure to seek advice or consult before illegally imposing an independent auditor on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), and leaving ATSIC responsible for any costs incurred;

(b) seeking to make changes to eligibility criteria for an ATSIC election which would come into effect after nominations had closed for that election, potentially threatening the validity of that election, thus incurring millions of dollars of additional costs for ATSIC;
(c) the inability to comprehend the outcomes of his own decisions which impact on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health, education, employment, social cohesion and self‐determination;
(d) the promotion of inappropriate and outdated policies of assimilation; and
(e) the willingness to allow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to be made scapegoats to deflect attention from issues of unemployment and growing inequalities in Australia.

While I was reading out those issues I heard people from the other side of the chamber saying that this is old. What we have today so far is an accumulation of points which lead up to this censure. I do not take such an issue lightly. This is the first time in three years in this place that I have moved a censure motion and it should be made very clear at the outset that my decision has not been taken lightly.

I have become increasingly concerned in recent times about the incompetence and insensitivity of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron). My motion refers to five key issues, and I will address my comments in relation to those matters.

The first issue is the actions of the minister in relation to the appointment of a special auditor to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. This decision was made early in the minister's time in his new portfolio and it has subsequently been found by the Federal Court that the minister had no power to set up the audit process. This flawed decision is indicative of an appalling lack of due care on its own, but it escalates to outrageous proportions when the financial implications of the decision are taken into account. There are huge hurts being felt by many people in terms of self-determination, but it is a slap in the face for people to find out that steps to move away from self-determination will actually be charged to those people who are most affected.

ATSIC was forced at the time of the appointment to set aside $750,000 to fund this special auditor, but this budget blew out to more than $830,000 within the first few weeks. The result of this bungle by the minister and his advisers is ATSIC is being forced to pay nearly $1 million. Will this have to be paid for by a reduction in services to Aboriginal communities?

Throughout this Senate there have been many occasions in industry or otherwise when the issue of some people not using funds as they were intended has been brought up. It has never been argued by the coalition in relation to industry that something like a 10 per cent figure in relation to funding for a program or a subsidy would mean that the program suddenly was frozen, the program suddenly was stopped or an independent auditor was immediately introduced. It certainly would not happen to business.

The second issue referred to in my motion is the debacle that occurred during the debate on the ATSIC Amendment Bill 1996 (No. 2). This bill dealt with structural changes to ATSIC and had some very important implications for the 1996 ATSIC elections. One of the changes was in relation to the eligibility criteria for ATSIC councillors, which my office determined immediately prior to the debate on this bill would take effect after nominations had closed for the 1996 election. This could have led to a situation in which the entire ATSIC elections, which cost millions of dollars to conduct, could have been deemed invalid.

It was only after this matter was raised with the minister and he at last realised the extraordinary implications of proceeding with those sections of the bill that amended eligibility criteria that the government decided to withdraw the offending section from this bill. I am pleased to say there was support from others in this chamber to do so. I am happy to provide advice to the minister, but perhaps I should be claiming higher duties allowance.

The third issue referred to in the censure motion is the inability of the minister to comprehend the outcomes of his own decisions which impact on the quality of life and the push for self-determination by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. There appears to be a denial of the fact that the funding that is currently provided to state, territory and local governments to provide such services as health or education to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities may simply be absorbed into those bodies' general revenue, leaving communities totally dependent either on ATSIC funding or on the royalties of mining, as is the case in the Northern Territory.

Where is the accountability in that? When people have talked about accountability, has anybody not mentioned to the minister that the accountability should be to the people to whom those services should be provided? If ATSIC is considered to be necessary for intervention by the government, how much more should state, territory and local governments be given when they are provided taxpayers' money at much greater levels to provide health, education and community services? How many of those dollars have been followed through to their final point? How many? How many areas only get access to royalties? How many areas virtually only get access to ATSIC funding?

We know that some health dollars are spent, but there is no tracing through, as far as I can see, to make sure that those dollars that are provided to those bodies get to where they are supposed to go. It is inevitable that, if you leave all other services to ATSIC, you will find they will be unable to provide all of those services to all of those communities. The funding is not accountable in that sense. We seem to have a very skewed opinion in relation to who should be targeted in this area.

Instead of providing greater self-determination, the minister is removing the decision making power from those bodies. The minister's response in not realising that ATSIC had been left with an impossible task is to cut funding for ATSIC programs. It should be said that this policy is largely poll driven, given the minister's preference for quoting polls, which he claims indicate that most Australians are not happy to see Aboriginal people receive more than their fair share of the taxpayers' dollars.

The minister's statements and actions reflect the mind‐set. This ignores the very real discrimination which has existed for Aboriginal people since the arrival of Europeans on this continent and whether or not those dollars which are down as being available to Aboriginal people which are going through state, territory and local governments are going to the point to which they are meant to be going. If that is indeed the case, the minister should tell us that it is so.

The fourth element of the censure motion refers to the promotion of inappropriate and outdated policies of assimilation. Many Aboriginal people bear the psychological scars which result from the paternalistic and assimilationist policies that dominated thinking on Aboriginal issues in this country until very recently. The minister's attitude to `the stolen generation' inquiry is reflective of this position. I have spoken to Aboriginal people in Western Australia who are friends of mine who have suffered greatly as a result of the policies that took them away from their parents. Those scars are not going to disappear quickly as a result of their speaking to the inquiry and, as the minister says, `getting it out of your system'. That was a recent statement by the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you quote his whole statement? Just for once be honest.

—I would be very happy if the entire interview was tabled in the Senate. I am happy for that to happen. If the minister has a copy of the entire interview, I would be happy to see it in the Senate as well.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I have spoken to Aboriginal people who are friends of mine who were taken away from their parents. Those scars are not going to disappear quickly. We only need to consider the impact of this forced separation on the former head of the Aboriginal Legal Service in Western Australia to realise the enormity of the task that we as a nation must confront.

The minister's statements on this and other matters has not helped in the process of reconciliation that must happen before we can move on, if there is a duty of care for ministers. If this involved a teacher, we would say that the teacher has breached their duty of care. It is quite clear that the minister considers that benefits have accrued to those who were forcibly separated from their parents. Perhaps he believes that these benefits are so great that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders do not feel real agony in telling strangers about their experiences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you quote the whole quote? Be honest for once. You charlatan.
—The minister says that he understands, we can be regretful, we can be sorry, we can be all those things, but we cannot change the past.
—You charlatan. You fraud. You are worse than the ABC.
—Order! Senator Campbell!

—If there was real understanding that we are dealing with real people going through real agony, surely there would be the understanding that there needs to be funding to provide counselling for those people.
—The main agony is listening to your verbal diarrhoea, my dear.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I object to the sexist comment coming from the senator opposite, but I guess it is part of his make‐up. However, I ask you to be firmer in having him restrict his interjections, which are disorderly. He will be given the opportunity to speak later, and should hear Senator Margetts in silence.
— Order! Senator Campbell, I think that perhaps some of the remarks that have been made could have been more carefully chosen. I would ask you to allow Senator Margetts to continue with her speech.

—There was acceptance by the minister that he regrets that the stolen generation was horrific, but at the moment we still do not have a report from the government. We still have a reluctance to admit that there was any liability from any government in the past. We have a situation which puts the entire process in limbo at this stage, when the federal government is the only government which has not provided a response.

SPEECH.PARA: If there was some true understanding and sensitivity, there would be the understanding that what is required is recognition—recognition that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are human beings and that whatever changes to their lifestyle there may have been as a result of being taken away from their parents, there is no substitution for that sense of identity that has been lost, that sense of loss of culture and that sense of loss of language. Only now are we seeing communities who are trying desperately to regain that sense of culture and that social cohesion to be able to teach language and culture to their children. At this point communities are realising that they need to regain some of what they have lost several generations on. That hurt and damage has lasted for several generations. As communities are trying to regain that sense of community, now is the vital time when that support should be given.

Whilst the minister may originally have made some unplanned gaffes due to inexperience, the poll‐driven response from the government has been to turn mistake into policy direction. If there is any real duty of care for ministers, this would have to be about as low as a government can stoop. It is convenient for the Howard government to use Aboriginal people as scapegoats to divert attention from both the decisions they made in concert with the previous government—which have severely affected the Australian community—and to justify their current slash and burn budget.

Yes, people were hurting going into the last election. There were many reasons why that was the case. They were promised that things would be as good as they could get. They were told to shut up because they had never had it so good. We had a growing gap between the rich and the poor; we had a growing working poor. We had people on part-time and casual jobs who found that that was the direction their jobs were going.

That disillusioned group of people did not have it explained to them why they were feeling the way they were, why the whole nature of their position in life—the future for their children in education and the nature of the workplace—was changing so rapidly. What is one of the reasons for that? No-one ever mentions it. I will tell you why, because of the isolation of many Aboriginal people in this country. I must say that I am pleased that someone is living to the north of this country of ours in a network of small communities, all with radio transceivers, in terms of the national interest, apart from anything else. The facts rather than the misconceptions are that, in terms of primary health care, which is the one that is always front and centre in here, despite the substantially greater need that Aboriginal people clearly have for these services that all Australians are entitled to, we spend about the same amount of money per head on Aboriginal primary health care as we do on the primary health care for every other Australian. A lot of those other myths can be exploded in the same way by simply comparing the quite proper expenditure of public money on the provision of essential services—sewerage, water supplies, police, nurses and teachers—to all small isolated communities in Australia, on which we have also spent hundreds of millions of dollars over the early part of this century. No-one, of course, ever puts that in the equation. Somehow or other isolated Aborigines are the only people in Australia who have ever had the need for that money to be spent on them. What nonsense!

A major detailed medical research project was recently done on the community of Maningrida in Arnhem Land. It was a detailed nuts and bolts study as to why people are dying early. Do you know why? Because that community which, if it were in rural Australia would probably have two doctors servicing it full time, has got one medical practitioner that visits it for three days a week. That is why.

People suffering from rheumatic heart disease who would, if they lived in urban Australia, be getting a prophylactic dose of penicillin about once a fortnight, I think, for the remainder of their lives to keep them in reasonable health, do not get it at all at Maningrida. Those six patients or however many there are out at Maningrida suffering from that disease who do not get this medication will die early as a result. That is why they are dying.

The reason I make that point is, for those of us who have been around a little longer than others who have recently come to this debate, the nonsense that is perpetrated again and again is that there has been no improvement in this situation over the last 13 years. Let me tell you what an utter falsehood that is. As bad as the situation is now, and it is, as urgent is the need—and I think the minister is sincere in his desire to fix it—to make it better, let me tell you, Minister, it is by quantum leaps better than it was 13 years ago. I do not link that to any particular government.

I am very familiar with the fact that the situation in communities has dramatically improved in respect of the quality of housing, the quality of health care and all the rest of it. Why then, and the minister knows this, do we still have the early mortality? Why is it still happening? Why are Aboriginal adults still dying early? I will tell you why. They are dying from the results of early childhood disease, which marked them out at a very early stage for a short life.

My close friend and colleague—whom I miss badly—the former member for Arnhem in the Northern Territory's parliament, died tragically at the age of 42 just a short time ago. His medical specialist from Adelaide told me himself that my friend had an enlarged heart as a result of an epidemic of rheumatic fever that went through Arnhem Land when he was four or five years old. He had simply lived with that legacy all his life. His medical specialist said to me—and I have not forgotten him saying it to me—that the situation was that he could live for another 10 years with very careful medical treatment or that he could die that afternoon. Both outcomes would be consistent with his medical condition. In other words, it did not matter a damn what improvements we have made in the last 10 or 20 years.

In respect of that one case—and it is a case which is symptomatic with many others—that Aboriginal person was marked out for an early death at the age of five. That simply emphasises again—and I know the minister is aware of it—the absolutely vital importance of early intervention in disease in Aboriginal communities. The depressing part is, Minister—particularly with the addition of things like substance abuse, which is horrific—that we are continuing to have generations of young Aboriginal people now, whom I know and you know and many others know, who are also going to be inevitably marked down for an early death.

It is wrong to say that there has been no improvement because of all this money that has been spent. There has, in fact, been a substantial improvement, particularly over the last decade. I might say with some feeling of regret that it is a matter of record also that a substantial increase in the allocation of those funds only occurred in the last four to five years of the previous government. That is the reason it is still happening. It is not because there are not results being gained from the expenditure of that money and not because those Aboriginal people are not entitled to it.

There is, in fact, a very simple health policy for this country, and I commend it to the minister. It is a health policy which, if it were put into effect in real terms, would actually result in a substantial improvement. That health policy should be simply this: all Australians, irrespective of where they live, should to the maximum extent possible have a level of health care commensurate with their needs. It is as simple as that.

If that care were provided—and in many cases I agree, Minister, it would be extremely expensive because of the isolation of those people to provide it—there would be a dramatic increase in the improvement of the health situation of Aboriginal people. There would be a far greater improvement than there has been over the last 10 years, as encouraging as it has been. But do not take the cheap political position of going to the statistics and saying, `Look at all this money. People are still dying early.' The fact is that they are often dying early because of things that happened generations ago.

Having dealt with that, I say to the Senate again that I intend to tackle a few more of these misconceptions in the Australian community which, to my great regret and sadness, people like the Prime Minister clearly and sincerely believe are true. They are not.

Let me conclude on the matter that was debated yesterday, and that is the minister's foray into the question of the stolen generation and the victims of that particular policy, which was administered by the Commonwealth government of the day under the Aboriginals Ordinances from 1910 to 1966, I think. That policy, misguided as it was and as horrific as it was in terms of the personal consequences for many of those people, is not yesterday's story. I know other speakers have said that and it is a fact. It is not. It is not something from the dim, dark regions of the past.

In my own family this year a 23-year-old girl—in fact, my wife's sister's daughter—was reunited with her mother, after having grown-up with a complete ignorance of her mother. The baby was removed from the mother when she had the baby at the age of 15. No correspondence was entered into. She was packed off down to Santa Teresa in the desert and had the baby. That daughter, whom she pined for and worried about all of her life, grew up in Darwin to the complete ignorance of both herself and her mother. The girl, through her own efforts, finally managed to trace a birth certificate and was reunited with her mother this year at the age of 23. These are not, in fact, very ancient stories at all. Rob Riley has been mentioned, and rightly so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made the point that it is occurring today.

—Indeed, Minister, and so you should have. He died in his early 40s. These are not yesterday's problems. The reason I make that in terms of your protestations is this: with great respect, I disagree with you that things that happened in the past cannot be redressed to at least some extent today. The courts of Australia—
—They can't be undone.
—Of course, they cannot be undone, but they can be redressed to some extent. The courts of Australia would be out of business if they could not.

BREAK.PARA: For example, and I mentioned this by way of interjection yesterday, last year our government in government—and I have to say I am pleased I voted for it in cabinet—paid out substantial damages at long last to the victims of the Voyager disaster, which happened 30 years ago. It is not a fact that the government that paid out the reparations was responsible for the accident that those reparations were paid out for but, of course, it was the only appropriate corporate body that should be and was responsible for those reparations. Aboriginal people are entitled to see it the same way.

I want to conclude with a letter to the editor from yesterday's Australian that I thought said it all, Minister. It was from Suzanne Midford, a clinical psychologist from Subiaco. I will read it into the Hansard because I think she said it better than I can. She said this:

I was appalled to read The Weekend Australian . . . the comments of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs Senator Herron on the past practice of forcible removal of Aboriginal children from their families.
The reality of the policy was extreme psychological and social trauma for the children . . .
The letter goes on to use this comparison:

By way of illustration, if a person loses the use of their legs through a trauma s/he may benefit from medical care and wheelchair technology. The person may even benefit from physical training and go on to play a sport—even go on to the Paralympics! Using Senator Herron's extraordinary logic could it be said that if a person won an Olympic medal that s/he had benefited from their paraplegia?
What nonsense! I think that the grounds for the censure debate have been made out in each and every sense. It is genuinely more in sorrow than in anger that I support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to agree with Senator Collins: I am sad that we are debating this issue once again. I really have to say that I think the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) has been given a poisoned chalice by the government, because he is a decent bloke, and I want to put that on the record. I think that he is having a terrible job of carrying the news to Aboriginal people about the bitterness, it seems to me, that this government has towards them. I feel very sad that this minister has been the one who has had to do this job, because I believe that, had the government left him alone to deliver services, he actually would have done that. But the government laid on him its own political agenda and he now is bearing the weight of that. That is a tragedy.

BREAK.PARA: Nevertheless, the Democrats want to associate themselves with this censure motion as being the only way to send a signal to the government that we want leadership from them in this area. We are not seeing it. The good work that I know the minister is doing is simply being totally counteracted by the failure of the government to address a number of problems in this community which are becoming far more than problems—in fact, they are becoming the source of great division and great agony for Aboriginal people, and Asian people as well. They are becoming a source of future real division and real disaster within this community.

Some of the debate has already been run and the Democrats believe there is no need to re‐run all that debate. Certainly the first four clauses in the censure motion have been dealt with in previous debates so I will only comment on those briefly, but I will spend a fair bit of time on clause 5. The first clause of this censure motion is as follows:
That the Senate censures the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs for his incompetent and insensitive handling of his portfolio in the following areas:
1) failure to seek advice or consult before illegally imposing an independent Auditor on ATSIC, and leaving ATSIC responsible for any costs incurred . . .

We do agree with this part of the censure motion. I believe that the minister could correct this if he would move, and argue in cabinet, for the government to pay the cost of that special auditor. In fact, as has been shown, it was illegal and there is no reason why ATSIC should have to pay between $800,000 and $1 million from its own budget. The questions remain: how many programs could have been run, how many jobs could have been funded and how many community centres could have benefited from this money? Yet it was taken from the budget with no recourse. It was a decision made in haste and without proper consultation.

I turn to the actions and lack of words of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). With Senator Collins, I do not believe the Prime Minister is an out‐and‐out racist, but I do believe he could have given far greater leadership—and he must. It will mean nothing to the Australian people if every senator in this place stands up and speaks. It is the leader of the government—the leader of the people—who must set an example and clearly indicate that he does not agree with what is happening in our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Governor‐General has done, I might add.

—As the Governor‐General has done. Thank you, Senator Collins, for reminding me of that. I remind the Senate that the Prime Minister, in his first ever press conference at Parliament House, implied that the indigenous people were crooks and that `we have to expose it all'. This was his theme. As has been proven since, it has set the tone under this government for a fast track backwards in terms of tolerance and reconciliation.

BREAK.PARA: I do not believe this minister himself believes that all Aborigines are crooks—in fact, I am sure he does not believe that—but his government has done little to correct this impression, and it is rife in the community. Every taxi driver you speak to and almost every person on the street is cheering, for they want an enemy to hate. They want a scapegoat upon whom they can lay all the ills of the community. There has been a horrendous increase in these reports. At the weekend the Young Democrats had a conference here in Parliament House. One of them, who is an Aboriginal person, spoke about the personal attacks that he has endured. He is a well‐educated young Aboriginal person who has really come to wonder whether he belongs to this country or not, because the government has failed to correct what is happening.

The hardship caused by the decision to appoint the auditor has been shocking for many organisations who lost funding or who had funding reduced. I might point out that, despite the rorting in other government programs, no‐one has suggested that every person in those programs is defrauding the system, but that has been the result of the failure of the government to correct this impression in the community. No‐one suggests that in fixing the fraud in other government programs many innocent people should be targeted, but this is the result: this is what has happened to Aboriginal people.

The second clause in the censure motion seeks to censure the minister for seeking to make changes to eligibility criteria, et cetera. I want to say that the potential was there for threatening the validity of the ATSIC election, but I believe the minister did correct that. The relevant clauses were withdrawn and we acknowledge that, Minister. That was an appropriate action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. Pity they didn't understand.
—The third clause states:

BREAK.PARA: The inability to comprehend the outcomes of his own decisions which impact on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health, education, employment, social cohesion and self‐determination.

Again, I want to underline that the Democrats believe, with great sadness, that this is the issue. I believe the minister is working flat out to correct that and I commend him for that. But let me say to you that it has had an awful impact on Aboriginal people.

Let us understand the original purpose of the CDEP. I remember, many years ago, visiting one of the first instances of this program having been put in place, in the Aboriginal communities of Ernabella and Fregon in the north of South Australia. A very wonderful Uniting Church deaconess, Win Hilliard, was involved in that program. Not only did the Aboriginal people benefit from the welfare payments which were paid through the CDEP; some of the profits from the craft shop also went into the program to be distributed to the community. What the minister and the government need to understand is that taking away funding for those programs is taking away money to which the people were entitled and which all other Australians are able to access. This action has deprived them of this money.

To help the Senate understand the impact of what we are doing to Aboriginal people in Australia, I might read an essay written by an Aboriginal boy quite some years ago, in the 1960s, when I was the Methodist minister in Mitchell—his teacher gave me this. This was an Aboriginal boy who wanted to be a doctor. He had the intelligence to get there but he did not make it because of the problems which he faced in those days. What I want to underline is that the Aboriginal people have come a long way in 30 years. They have done it mostly by their own efforts, but with some help from the Australian community. We need to understand that Aboriginal people want to make a contribution to this country but they cannot make it if they feel that they are constantly being excluded. Let me read the essay—at the time he was in grade 7:
The situation of my home is east Mitchell . . .
That was on the other side of the Maranoa River from the main township of Mitchell. He lived in one of the fringe camps of those days. He continues:
I live beside the Forest Vale Road. It has no name for we live in the bush not far from town.
My farther built the house out of tin and it is not a very good house, for he didn't build it on a slant and therefore when it rains the water stays in the middle and it leaks.
I help him to construct the house while mum prepared the tin.
We do not know the size of it for it is in a rectangular form. Our interior is not good for we have newspaper on the wall, to keep the wind from coming through the cracks, in the wall.

Also our home is envirous with sand and therefore we can't make ours look beautiful. Flowers will not grow because it is sandy and dry. Although we have no electricity or water layed on we have a kerosene lantern and we pay Mr Morgan five shillings to carry us some water. He carries the water in five gallon drums.
Maintening our house is easy for us. We don't do anything to our house only when it rain and we put tar where it leak or put chewing gum in the hole from which the water is coming.

At home, we don't have room for we only have one rectangular room, in the corner is a double bed where Michal and I sleep. Mum and Dad sleep under a half a tank with a bit of tent over their head. For pets we have eight ducks, seven dogs, and four cats. From the ducks we have fine eggs and the cats keep the snakes away.
Well I've told you of my home. I know it not much of a home but to me it is therefore I will always call it my home.

That story tells us two things. One is that the people of the Yumba camp have all gone from there now and they live in the main township. That is the good news. The bad news is that there are still hundreds and thousands of Aboriginal people living in camps where the same description would apply. Minister, we live in a community which, indeed, is able to repair some of these stories. It is not something that happened in the past; we have a task to do today.

The fourth issue which was raised in the censure motion was the promotion of inappropriate and outdated policies of assimilation. I must say I was disappointed that the minister promoted the book about Hasluck's assimilation policies. I know the minister gets hundreds of invitations and he has to make choices about what he will or will not promote. I believe it was a deliberate and bad choice to launch the book, but it does give us an understanding, by default, of the thinking of this government.

To say that many indigenous people benefited from being forcibly removed from their families is to support one of the cornerstones of assimilation. It is a remark which has brought pain to many people and has put a spin on the outcome of the stolen generation inquiry which was unnecessary and just wrong. I have spent 35 years living, working and struggling with Aboriginal people within Aboriginal communities. I helped set up the Aboriginal child‐care agency in Brisbane—and I must say that working with those people to recover some of those children was a very poignant and telling experience for me.

I turn to the fifth clause in the censure motion. In some ways, I do not think this should be directed as much to the minister as to the Prime Minister because I underline again that the failure to correct the impression being left in this community in fact is making Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people into scapegoats. The phenomenon of scapegoating has a long and inglorious history. Through the centuries, people have been made scapegoats where a minority group which is easily identifiable and living on the edge of society is accused of being the basis for all that is wrong in that society. In times of social instability, the rise of scapegoating is something which we can note in history and something about which we ought to be really concerned.

The creation of an enemy—where a group of people is identified, then vilified, then brutalised and finally eliminated as a public service—has historical precedents which, I think, give all of us pause. I would like to underline that by pointing out that the story of scapegoating, or the whole idea of scapegoating, has a very long history. It really comes out of the Old Testament. It is a story that comes out of an ancient Jewish ritual. In Leviticus 16, on the day of atonement, a goat was paraded in front of the tabernacle. The sins of the people were laid on the head of the goat by the priest. The goat was taken into the desert and released, presumably to starve to death. Its fate was of no further concern to the people.

Thus, in our modern culture, a scapegoat is one identified in the mind of the community as a focus for all that is wrong with society. It is vilified as one to whom the blame for all the community's ills can be attributed. It is cast out to the edges of society where its fate is of no further concern because the community has laid on its head all of that community's guilt and responsibility. That process is happening and many people in the Australian community are endorsing that very action and that process. We need, from this government, a very strong statement to the contrary so that we can say that this is not on.

It sounds depressingly familiar as we recount the ancient story. It is not so much an ancient Jewish ritual as it is a modern political parable, except that we are not talking about casting out symbolic goats to wander around in the desert: we are talking about the lives and the future of real people, real Australians. We are talking about laying on the heads of Aboriginal Australians, in particular, the failure of our society to deliver a fair deal to all of its citizens.

I trust that the Senate will pass this censure motion so that we can get a new direction from this government and clearly hear that they do not support this process and that, in the end, they will agree that those who are most disadvantaged in our community have the right to expect from its government a far better deal than they have been getting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond seriatim to the censure motion and go through it point by point. I vigorously respond, and I will detail in my response the fact that all of these points can be adequately refuted. In relation to clause 1, the special auditor process and the independent auditor, the government stated that it was committed to accountability. We will not step back from that process of accountability or from the fact that we did appoint a special auditor.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the special auditor process has been extremely worth while, and, interestingly enough, so does ATSIC. The ATSIC chief executive officer has written to the government indicating that the special auditor process has been of considerable value and will be used to help to decide future funding determinations. The background was the Federal Court decision that the general direction establishing a special auditor was too specific. It was the first time a general direction had been used. It was new territory and the court challenge was the first time general directions had been tested.

Legal advice is, in fact, that the decision could be appealed but, as the audit process was virtually complete, there seemed little point, and a great deal of taxpayers' money would be spent through the legislative process. I saw no point in doing that when it was virtually completed at the time the court decision was handed down, so I did not proceed along that process. At the time of the special court decision, 95 per cent of the special auditor process had been completed. ATSIC agreed to complete the process and used the material gathered by the special auditor to assist in funding decisions.

We are still awaiting the final report from the special auditor; I hope to table it today or tomorrow. The preliminary report shows that the special auditor has found that 19 per cent of all organisations funded by ATSIC were in serious breach of grant conditions and 60 organisations which received $27.8 million in their last ATSIC grant should be declared not fit and proper and de‐funded. At the time of the court decision, the special auditor was seeking additional information on a further 130 organisations that received $89.6 million in their latest funding. Of these organisations, the special auditor says:
There is the potential for some or all to be declared not fit and proper.

The special auditor has found that a further 184 organisations were in such serious breach of grant conditions that they require immediate and close attention. They received a total of $124 million in their latest funding. Altogether, that is a total of 374 of the 1,300 organisations funded by ATSIC in serious breach and either not fit and proper or requiring close and immediate attention. Those 374 organisations received a total of $241 million in their latest ATSIC grants.

As a result of the special auditor process, ATSIC has implemented tighter internal funding requirements. Senator Margetts said `some blunder'—when we have the special auditor reporting on that volume of money that has been found and will be found as a result of this process. As I said, ATSIC itself is adopting the procedures to tighten this up.

The initial cost of the special auditor was expected to be around $750,000. That figure was based on an estimate that 60 per cent of ATSIC funded organisations would be in compliance with their grant conditions. In fact, less than 20 per cent were in compliance, which increased substantially the number of organisations requiring close examination; therefore, the cost increased. The final cost is still to be settled on, but it is expected to be in excess of $1 million. ATSIC budgeted $1.2 million for the special auditor and the money is from running costs, not from the programs, which is another essential point that needs to be made.

In summary, the special auditor process has forced the 80 per cent of organisations classified as amber into compliance and others in serious breach to either undergo substantial remedial action or lose their funding. For the first time, and as a direct result of the special auditor process, we will be able to move forward with confidence from a baseline that sees all ATSIC funded organisations either in full compliance or undertaking changes to bring them into full compliance.

BREAK.PARA: I think those facts completely refute the first part of the censure motion. I have no doubt it will be accepted by the Senate itself as being a complete travesty that that first part of the censure motion should be proposed in the light of the figures I have just released.

The second part of the censure motion was seeking to make changes to eligibility. This is even better hypocrisy on their behalf. I thank Senator Woodley for pointing it out to the Greens, who moved this motion. The second part of the motion reads:

. . . seeking to make changes to eligibility criteria for an ATSIC election which would come into effect after nominations had closed for that election, potentially threatening the validity of that election, thus incurring millions of dollars of additional costs for ATSIC;

I am not sure where Senator Margetts was when the ATSIC amendments passed the Senate, but the government moved to remove the eligibility criteria from the amendments. The eligibility criteria were there because government had hoped to pass amendments back in June when first introduced, well in advance of the ATSIC election. There was never any threat to the election process. The government was in full agreement with the removal of these provisions.

I do not really know what Senator Margetts is about. We did remove them and now she comes in with a censure motion that I sought to make changes to eligibility criteria, et cetera. The eligibility criteria are not there. They certainly did not add any additional cost to ATSIC and did not threaten the validity of the election. The government's legal advice at the time was that the provision changing the eligibility rules for the current ATSIC election would not have threatened the legal validity of the election. So point No. 2 is knocked out of the ring. Let us move to point No. 3. Point No. 3 of the motion states:
The inability to comprehend the outcomes of his own decisions which impact on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health, education, employment, social cohesion and self‐determination.

I am more than aware of the outcomes of the decisions of this government—more than anyone in this chamber, including Senator Margetts, and Senator Brown I might say. After traversing the length and breadth of this land over the last seven months, never have I heard their names mentioned or seen them physically in any of the remote Aboriginal communities in this country. They may well have been there, but virtually every moment that this chamber has not been sitting I have been traversing this country and I would have thought that at some stage I would have come across them. I have come across the members of the opposition around the country.

When I talk to indigenous people and ask their opinions on what action needs to be taken, I find that what is offered is at complete variance with what I hear in this chamber. Last Wednesday I spoke to the Central Land Council, 120 kilometres north of Tennant Creek and 80 Aboriginal traditional owners there. They were at complete variance with what I hear in this chamber. I am actually out speaking to people in the communities and listening to their concerns.

In the last seven months I have visited more than 50 communities. I can tell you that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in those communities are pleased and relieved that at last a government is taking action to improve health, education and employment conditions for indigenous Australians, which is what we quarantined in the budget so that the money would go there. Total Commonwealth spend on indigenous specific programs for 1996-97 will be $1.6 billion, the second highest amount on record.

Clearly, Senator Margetts, you are the ones that have failed to comprehend. You do not comprehend that there is a new government in office. You have failed to comprehend that the policies of the past 13 years have been an unqualified failure in the very respects you are pointing out. I take Senator Bob Collins's point and I support him in that: there is a lot of ignorance out in the wider community because they do not have the privilege to go out. You have no excuse. You as senators could travel around, but the general community does not have the opportunity to go around these remote communities and talk to these people. You fail to comprehend that that has occurred. I welcome you to come along so that you can meet these people and not be listening to what you are hearing in this chamber.

The Greens fail to comprehend that this government will not play the politically correct game if it means that Aboriginal people on the ground in remote communities continue to miss out, which is what they have been doing. They fail to comprehend that this government is about achieving real outcomes for indigenous Australians.

There are 300,000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australia, fewer than 100,000 adults. In the past 12 years, over $16,000 million has been spent on indigenous specific programs, and I welcome that. As Senator Collins said, it has been only belatedly in the last four or five years that that has increased. Despite that increase, indigenous Australians still have an infant mortality rate two to three times that of non-indigenous Australians, a life expectancy up to 18 years less than non-indigenous Australians, adult diabetes at four times the rate for non-indigenous Australians and falling education standards.

Those opposite would have us continue those same failed policies. We are not going to do that. Instead, we have embarked on policies that will deliver real outcomes. Despite the savings within the ATSIC budget, during the next four years the Commonwealth will spend in today's dollar terms $428 million more on indigenous specific programs than was spent during the last four years.

If you listened to the rhetoric of this chamber, you would think it was the end of the world that these dramatic cuts were occurring. The fact is that savings have been made in the ATSIC budget, but we have increased the funding in health care and in education for the next four years specifically for the very reasons that Senator Brown was decrying. We are doing that, Senator Brown, and I wish you would read the debate and read the budget papers to see that it is occurring. We are spending an additional $97 million on indigenous health in the next four years. We are spending an additional $26 million on the community housing and infrastructure program.

I am delighted that the week before last I went with the minister responsible for housing, Senator Newman, to a conference and we got the states to agree on indigenous housing. I thank Senator Newman for inviting me to that conference in Darwin of all the state housing ministers. There was general agreement that the funding would be put together from the states and the Commonwealth and that indigenous housing would be specifically approached. For the first time, Senator Brown, indigenous specific funding will go to indigenous people with regard to housing. It was a move by Senator Newman, which was totally supported by me. I thank her for the invitation to attend, and I thank the state ministers for housing for agreeing to that.

We put a press release out on that matter, but it did not get a run. It never got a mention. I am sorry, Senator, you probably were not aware of that event because it did not get a run in the media. Good news does not get a run in the media.

In addition to housing, we are spending an extra $337 million on the community development employment programs—CDEP. An additional $147 million will be spent on the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs to run indigenous education and training programs.

I will say it again, and I will keep saying it until it gets through the minds of those opposite: extra funding is going into health, education, housing and the work for the dole scheme. That is going in. That is in the budget papers. I hope you can pay a little attention to them so you do not come in here making these statements in relation to the third item.

We have successfully negotiated bilateral health agreements with the states and territories, which will see improved outcomes for indigenous Australians. I thank my colleague the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) for negotiating those, and nearly all the states and territories have signed up on them. They are very positive achievements, and they will achieve outcomes.

We have gained an agreement, as I mentioned, with housing. Finally—and I put this clause in—indigenous Australians themselves have control and will be consulted in relation to housing. Senator Woodley is a bit behind the pace, and I can understand that too because he was probably not aware of that fact as it did not get any reportage. The very first clause of that agreement is that indigenous people be consulted and have control over the expenditure of funding in relation to housing. As I mentioned, I am grateful to the housing ministers for getting that through. That is your point No. 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three‐nil.

—That is three‐nil. Let us go to item No. 4—the promotion of inappropriate and outdated policies of assimilation. I would like you to show me where I have promoted assimilation. The best that you could level at me was that I launched a book here. I presume that is what you are referring to. I have never promoted assimilation—never. I would like you to show me otherwise anywhere on the record. I know that I have not.

BREAK.PARA: I did launch a book. Senator Woodley was kind enough to say that I do receive many invitations to launch things. It was a book expressing views, and I stated when I launched it that I did not agree with it. I made it perfectly clear at the launch, and have done so on numerous occasions since then. Where have you been, Senator Margetts? Where have you been, Senator Brown? Did you not see that? If I were to launch a book on the recent history of China, would that mean I supported communism? That is your implication. The government is on record as opposing assimilation policies. They are the policies of the past.

I also do not agree with book burning. I happen to love books. I was on the library committee here from the first day I was in. I believe in promoting knowledge, promoting debate and promoting reading. If we followed your mentality, we would burn the books and try to confine information so it was only divulged along one political line.

I am not about book burning and I will not censor or edit Australia's history. It is a fact of history. We must look at the past to learn from the mistakes and ensure that they are not repeated. To ignore the past and the mistakes that occurred is to try to pretend that what happened then did not really happen. I am not prepared to do that.

This government is about greater self‐management for indigenous Australians. It is about encouraging indigenous Australians to take hold of their own destiny and work towards greater independence at all levels. That is why we have committed most of the $428 million increase in indigenous spending over the next four years to the areas of health, housing, education and training. Without real outcomes in those areas, self-determination will mean little. It is a nonsense to suggest this government is pursuing assimilation policies. I will say again, and I have done so repeatedly over the last few months, that I do not endorse assimilation policies and never have done so. So that is four‐nil.
Let us go to point No. 5 of the motion, the final one. It says:
. . . the willingness to allow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to be made scapegoats to deflect attention from issues of unemployment and growing inequalities in Australia.

This government is committed to improving outcomes for indigenous people, unlike its predecessors, and in the just over seven months that we have been in government we have taken major steps towards this goal. The Labor government was in office for 13 years and there were some improvements, as Senator Collins has noted—I agree with him in that regard—but there is still an enormous amount to be done.

We have taken immediate action to ensure that funds are getting through to Aboriginal people in the communities and they are not going to be unnecessarily wasted on rorts and bureaucracy. Senator Margetts and her colleagues should spend more time visiting Aboriginal communities because people out there are telling me that they are supporting what the government is doing and that it has been long overdue. It is the negative sorts of politically correct statements, such as those made by Senator Margetts here today, that undermine the reconciliation process.

This government will not sit around and watch the further destruction of Aboriginal communities through neglect. The previous government wooed Aboriginal people with false promises. We remember Graham Richardson going out into the communities. He regarded them as great photo opportunities. I am going to go back to that community and I will report back to the Senate what occurred as a result of that. I suspect I know the answer already because I have done a little preliminary investigation. But I will produce the facts, not just empty rhetoric.

In fact, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner, Mick Dodson—certainly not one of my wildest supporters—in the West Australian of 23 September 1996 launched an attack on the Labor Party and former Prime Minister Bob Hawke, saying that they had done little to advance the indigenous cause. That was in the West Australian of 23 September 1996, which Senator Margetts should review.

The government will not repeat this pattern. To say that we are allowing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to be made scapegoats to deflect attention from other issues is ridiculous and highly divisive. We are not going to function in the looney left paradigm of the past. This government is working to the empowerment of Aboriginal people and their recognition as equals in a just society. Equality of opportunity, equality of education and equality in health care and housing is the emphasis of this government. We do not believe that they should be locked into the politics and the rhetoric of the past, where they were government dependent. We believe in economic independence and pride in Aboriginality and protection of culture, not in government dependence, which is the paradigm of the opposition and the looney left. We are not committed to that at all.

I thank Senator Collins because he made some constructive remarks in relation to health. But I suppose in a sense he said he was doing it more in sorrow than in anger. I can understand that because I look back to 5 May 1993 and the headlines of the day—`Collins should resign', `Collins, the minister for the pay TV fiasco' and `Cabinet had four chances over two years to reject the new system and wrecked it'. I suppose he has a sense of deja vu, but he did make some constructive comments.

I was up at the Menzies School of Health Research last week. It is funny; life is interesting. I was on the committee that made the decision for the Menzies Foundation—I was the inaugural Queensland chairman of it—to devote funds for the establishment of the Menzies school for tropical health and research in Darwin. I launched the acute rheumatic fever booklet, but we have heard not a word. It is true that Aboriginals have a lot of problems in relation to health. They are related to low birth weight and immunity. Nobody knows why, but by the time an Aboriginal child is nine months of age, they are colonised with bacteria and their immune system is deficient because of the low birth weight. There are a lot of problems associated with Aboriginal health. We cannot blame that on the conditions that are there.
Senator Collins mentioned the CDEP. He asked the following question on notice:

Is it a fact that KPMG Peat Marwick must advise of any conflict of any interest before a replacement special auditor is appointed; if so, what has been the extent of any time delays which have occurred in having a special auditor begin work on affected organisations . . .
The answer was:
KPMG must obtain the Commonwealth's permission . . . The Commonwealth has not been advised of any delays in having the alternate Special Auditor beginning work on affected organisations.
The second question he asked was:
Has this resulted in delays to Community Development and Employment Projects (CDEP) payments from ATSIC to any organisations; if so, how many, and are those delays still occurring?

The answer was no. Did he come back to the Senate and tell us—that was the part of the last censure motion, if you recall—about these terrible delays that were resulting in CDEP payments? Of course he did not come back and apologise to the Senate for misleading us, which is what he did at the time.

I thank Senator Woodley. Like Senator Woodley, I will not introduce personality into this. It is not, as Senator Woodley said, that I have been sold a dump. I regard this as a wonderful opportunity. It is the most wonderful portfolio to have. I have had the opportunity to meet some outstanding Aboriginal leaders in this country—not the ones you read about in the papers every day but, for example, the Yirrkala business enterprises who have a contract from Comalco for $60 million over the next 20 years to transport alumina to the plant up at Nhulunbuy. Do we hear about that? No, not a word. There are outstanding Aboriginal people. I invite Senator Margetts and Senator Brown to come with me next time and I will introduce them to these people so that they can meet the true leaders of the Aboriginal community who are working towards economic dependence and who are not locked into the politics and rhetoric of the past.
I refute this censure motion. I believe that any honest minded senator would not support this censure motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There are obviously a number of points that have been canvassed in today's debate. Most of it has been a very sad debate. Whatever the outcome of today's debate, it has been important for these issues to be canvassed and is important for the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) and the government to see that the parliament and the community are watching and that they do not swallow the kind of statements and attitudes that are coming out from this government via decisions that are being made by this minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Point No. 1 of the motion said that there was a failure to seek proper advice or consult before imposing an independent auditor on ATSIC. That is what the courts clearly said. It was a unanimous decision. Whatever the outcomes of the audit, there are provisions within ATSIC for that audit to take place. The problem was the failure to consult and get proper advice before that action took place. Whatever people have said about the outcomes of the auditor, they do not address the situation that proper advice was not sought and proper consultation did not take place before that decision took place. Ministers should not act in that way.

In relation to point No. 2, the fact that the change was made to the bill on the day in the chamber was the result of advice given by the Greens to the minister. Yes, the minister withdrew it. I obviously know that— everybody knows that—because, despite the preliminary and inadequate advice the minister received, the information that the minister gave me that there was no problem did not constitute a legal advice. It was simply an advice from the Electoral Commission that such an election could take place within the time specified.

So, whilst the minister says, `I received advice that it was okay,' he clearly knows that that advice was not a legal opinion and did not comment in any way upon whether or not such a move would make or would not make the election ineligible. Of course, most of those issues would require a court challenge to establish that absolutely.

That does not change the fact that the minister did seek to make changes. There is nothing at all that the minister can say to indicate that he did not seek to make changes to the eligibility criteria for the ATSIC election. Of all the people looking at the bill, if it requires the Greens at the last minute to save $4.7 million, then it should be acknowledged it was on the basis of that decision. It was because of incompetence on the part of a number of people, including perhaps department and minister, that that situation got that far.

Point No. 3 relates to health, education, employment, and so on. The minister said, `I have not seen the Greens in remote communities.' In the last five weeks I have been speaking to Aboriginal people in Darwin, Jabiru, Alice Springs, Uluru—

—No, in person.
