—My question is addressed to Senator Newman representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. I refer the minister to the three 5.1 per cent increases in health insurance premiums put forward by the National Mutual subsidiaries. How many further applications for insurance premium rises are pending; and is it not a fact that the health insurance rebates are now practically worthless as a result of these premium increases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The detail of the senator's question obviously makes it one for the minister responsible, Mr Wooldridge. The number of applications that have been flowing through the system for an increase in private health insurance premiums is a direct result of the previous government's failure to take action to encourage people to stay in private health insurance. I well remember when I was the shadow minister for health and the then Senator Richardson was keenly trying to do something to encourage private health insurance. But he was stamped on from a great height by his Prime Minister Mr Keating. So precious years were wasted while action could have been taken to make private health insurance more attractive to Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: The present government, as soon as it had the opportunity in its first budget, announced the measures which are going to be implemented to encourage people to stay in private health insurance. The Labor opposition, I gather, has got some sort of mean‐spirited approach to this, that it does not believe Australians should get assistance in terms of affordability of private health insurance. If that is their ideological stance, it suggests that they are going even further to the left than they have been in the past. That will be a great shame if it means that older Australians who desperately want to stay in private health insurance are prevented from affording it and that families, with children particularly, will find it difficult.

You may be aware, Madam President, that the Minister for Health and Family Services just recently has been talking to the health funds, trying to encourage them to introduce new and innovative measures which will make the opportunity for private health insurance more attractive to special elements of the community. I will be very happy to get any details which the minister is able at this stage to give me. I am not, of course, going to be in a position to bring an answer back to the Senate which predicts which health funds might have applications pending because, as you would know, Madam President, health funds are only able to get confirmation of their applications for an increase in private health insurance where their reserves have dropped to such a level that they need support through extra funding.

The situation is that, as more and more people drop out of private health insurance, the pressures on the reserves of those funds grow greater. So, for each year that no action was taken, the problem has grown greater and greater and greater. While there can be the odd bit of mirth and interjection from the other side, they know full well where the guilty party is because we would not be facing this problem, this pressure on Medicare by the failure of people who can afford it to take up private health insurance—people like the Keating family.

Madam President, as you will recall, when I was the shadow minister, I pointed out how hard it was for battlers in the community to have to take a place in the queue with people on very high incomes, like Prime Ministers and others on such incomes. It is not fair to battlers in Australia to have the rich battening onto the system. That is why we have taken the supplementary action of increasing the Medicare levy for people on high incomes. That is surely fair in a fair country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am a little disappointed that the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services is unable to answer—

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much audible conversation in the chamber.

—on an issue which is of such fundamental importance to a large number in the Australian community. But while she is asking the minister the answer to the previous question, firstly, could she also find out from the minister what the net worth of the rebate will be in light of the premium increases in private health insurance since the budget; and, secondly, could the minister tell us what increased percentage participation in private health insurance is anticipated to come about annually as a result of the private health insurance rebates?

—This sounds to me like a series of new questions rather than a supplementary. Nevertheless, this is an opposition which is badly in need of education on this subject, and I will be very happy to get as much information for Senator Neal as I possibly can that will help her.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Newman. Minister, you would be aware of recent comments by several former Labor politicians who endorse the Howard government's policies in the areas of health, aged care and housing—which comments, I might say, are in stark contrast with those of the few remaining members of the Labor Party in this parliament. Minister, can you explain the benefits of the changes announced in the budget?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be delighted to make the opposition better informed, because clearly they are in great need of tutorials. They do have difficulty with the fact that this budget was the most popular in Australia for 20 years. That really sticks in the craws of the opposition. Of course, it can be made even worse for them when they see that former Labor politicians have been queuing up to endorse the measures and to endorse what we are doing.

ANSWER.PARA: You may recall that I reported in the last week of sitting that former Senator Graham Richardson had endorsed the higher Medicare levy for high income earners. He said that he bemoaned Labor's failure to implement such a policy themselves. I just referred to that in my answer to the previous question. It is interesting to note that he is now endorsing yet another area in our health policy. In his Bulletin column he says:
I hope Michael Wooldridge . . . stands his ground and limits Medicare provider numbers for new medical graduates from November.

He recognised back in 1993 that the problem with the oversupply of doctors was getting totally out of hand and that action needed to be taken. He spoke to the vice‐chancellors—without much success, I gather. He also spoke to the AMA and told them that action needed to be taken. He pointed out that, whatever the colour of the government, action was going to have to be taken. And that is why he endorses what Michael Wooldridge has done recently about the provider numbers and why he says that he should not give in.
There is also Gary Johns, another former minister, who in a letter to the Australian vigorously supported our aged care reforms—and it was a very well reasoned and detailed letter to the editor.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Gary Johns say? He said that it is entirely fair that those who use these facilities should make a contribution.
—Order! There is far too much conversation in the chamber, making it difficult to hear.

—The noise is coming from the rabble, the people who sat on their hands for all those years and saw our nursing home stock deteriorate through lack of funds. Mr Johns also went on to say that there are more than 400,000 people over the age of 80, and that that number may well double by 2021, so the capital required to upgrade and build homes will be huge.

ANSWER.PARA: We in this government are prepared to make the hard decisions to ensure that the aged in Australia do receive the best possible care. That is something which Mr Johns recognised when he said:

My generation will inherit the largest stock of capital ever in the nation's history, and generally we earn better than our parents. It seems fair, then, to use some of that inheritance to keep up a good quality of care for those who need it.

We see the sense in these reforms. All the stakeholders in the aged care sector support the reforms; even Gary Johns supports the reforms. But, of course, the people who are having trouble finding a place in opposition just have no alternative policy about how to care for older Australians in the 21st century, and so they oppose the reforms. They are important measures which need to be passed by the Senate.

It is not only the right‐wing former Labor ministers who are endorsing the new government. Brian Howe, surely a pillar of the Left, supports us as well. I found it very interesting listening to Mr Howe the other day being interviewed on an ABC program entitled Life Matters. He spoke at length about the housing reforms. Of course, he initiated them, and we, in opposition, gave bipartisan support to the reforms which Brian Howe was introducing. We have continued the process. These are measures which are going to be of inestimable advantage for those million people, roughly—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, are you aware that at an estimates hearing on 24 September your departmental officials said that the Tasmanian dole cheat hotline pilot scheme had not yet been evaluated? Are you also aware that on 25 September the West Australian reported your spokeswoman as saying the Tasmanian trial was evaluated and that you were fully briefed on its success and national potential before making the decision to expand the program? Minister, who is correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, a formal full evaluation, as, perhaps, the department would describe it, has not been undertaken. Nevertheless, a report was given to me by the department, which I presume is what my spokesman was referring to, on the success of the scheme. On the basis of the report that I was given on the Tasmanian pilot, I confirmed that we would take this scheme national. I have noticed that Senator Faulkner, the opposition spokesman, has been very ready to peddle quite inaccurate facts about this.
—It is very hard to pedal without your right foot.
—I think the problem may be that Senator Faulkner did not fall only on his ankle; maybe another extremity was in trouble as well.

ANSWER.PARA: I would point out also to the Senate that the phone calls coming in to the national hotline for employers around Australia are now running at something like 100 a day. Employers are finding it particularly helpful because it means that they are not required to fill in as many forms and do as much paperwork for the department as has been required in the past.

Before we came into government we made it very clear that we would be looking to see what measures we could introduce that would reduce the paperwork burden that government places on business. In the social security area this is one matter that we have undertaken. It has been well received by employers. I am advised by the department that, in fact, they expect the 100 calls a day to grow substantially in the future, because more employers, as they become aware of the number and the fax line, will take up the use of it.

I know the previous government had a problem in communicating especially with small to medium sized business and they thought that their concerns were never listened to by the previous government. This government has listened to their concerns. They know that employers want questions answered about activity testing measures, about entitlements that come through either DSS or DEETYA, and this scheme has been a very useful facility for business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it true, Minister, that you were not aware of the evidence that was given by your departmental officials because you did not attend that meeting and did not send a representative? Is it also true that your departmental officials reported that there were 30 dob ins out of over 3,000 calls—a less than one per cent dob in rate? Is it also true that of those 30 calls none of those has yet been substantiated? I ask you, Minister, not whether there was a report but whether was there an evaluation as your officials said? What were the findings and what was the department's estimate of the national potential of the pilot scheme? Minister, will you provide the Senate with a copy of the evaluation?

—The shadow minister is trying to score a cheap political point when he tries to portray me as having not attended the estimates committee hearings. The first day that I attended the social security hearings I sat there for a long time while Senator Faulkner tried to find his way around the performance statements for the department. Having said that, I point out that the night before the second hearing I became ill and at short notice there was not a minister available to take my place. So that was a pretty cheap shot from Senator Faulkner. Secondly, the shadow minister has clearly made a mistake in what the employer contact unit was all about. He reads the headlines in the papers obviously but he does not read what the government documents are all about. It is not a dob in line. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware of forecasts suggesting that the government's economic strategy will help take the pressure off interest rates and benefit Australian families and small businesses?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise for anybody to hear what is being said.

—Could the minister explain in what way the govern ment's economic strategy would do this? Could the minister also explain the critical importance to the Australian economy of the government being allowed to keep its promises it made to the Australian people and to have its budget pass through the Senate in its entirety?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ian Macdonald for that question and for the keen appreciation he shows and his recognition, as I hope all Australians recognise, of the need to take pressure off interest rates. The government is committed to delivering an interest rate environment which provides significant material benefit to all Australian families and small businesses. That is in stark contrast to the record of the previous Labor government whose interest rate policies as a result of overall economic incompetence forced thousands and thousands of small businesses into bankruptcy and imposed enormous hardships and burdens on most Australian families.

ANSWER.PARA: We are absolutely committed to taking pressure off interest rates. Under Labor, Australia had amongst the highest interest rates in the world. We had the second highest prime interest rate of any of the OECD countries, the western countries, and higher interest rates than most other of our major trading and competitor countries. In one four‐month period alone under Labor, interest rates in Australia rose by no less than three per cent.

A key cause of that was Labor's failure to run responsible prudent fiscal policy. By running up huge deficits, $70 billion worth of deficits over a five‐year period alone, which left an inheritance for the new incoming government of $100 billion, Labor failed to tackle our No. 1 problem—a shortage of national savings. By failing to tackle that national savings problem, they failed to take pressure off interest rates and put pressure on interest rates to be much higher than they should have otherwise been.

Moreover, during Labor's term in office, they presided over two downgradings to our international credit rating which further increases the cost of borrowing by Australia overseas. Our budget strategy will return the budget to balance over the next three years. By doing that, we will directly boost public and national savings. Increased national savings equals less pressure on interest rates. It is a very simple equation which Labor never seems to have been able to come to grips with. That means that families struggling to pay off a mortgage will benefit from lower repayments. It means that businesses pay less interest on business loans, helping them to expand, helping the economy to grow faster, helping to create more jobs throughout the economy.

Senator Macdonald also asked me about the critical importance to the economy of getting this budget passed in full. I want to stress this. Let there be no mistake at all about this that any diminution of the government's fiscal consolidation strategy risks putting more pressure on interest rates. The budget should have been in surplus in 1995-96 if the former government was serious about Australian families and business. Instead it was in deficit by $10 billion and when they left office, as I said, it was $100 billion. The Australian people have had to pay very heavily for this fiscal incompetence and are well aware of it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that clear indication. I was interested in his comments about the impact interest rates have on families. It is apparent that Australian families with a mortgage—and those in western Sydney in the electorate of Lindsay would be included in this—have already benefited quite considerably through the interest rate reductions which have taken place since the coalition government won office. I ask the minister whether he could explain for the benefit of the Australian people, particularly for those opposite who obviously have no understanding of this, how this happened?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ian Macdonald for that supplementary question. I have explained just how much importance the government places on helping families and businesses through interest rate relief. We have done that, we have delivered and we will continue to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: Since Labor was thrown out of office in March, variable home mortgage rates offered by the four major banks have fallen by around 1¼ percentage points from 10½ per cent to 9¼ per cent. Their fixed rates have fallen by even more than that. To use Senator Ian Macdonald's example of a family in Lindsay, a family with a 25-year, $100,000 loan—a typical loan nowadays—will have enjoyed an $88 per month reduction in repayments as a result of that fall in home mortgage rates. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. You have repeatedly defined `a surcharge' as a surcharge. Do you accept the ABS classification of `a tax' as compulsory levies imposed by government to raise revenue? Further, it says `there is usually no clear and direct link between payment of taxes and the provision of goods and services'. You also stated in answer to a question on notice from me that your government does not intend to change the classification adopted by the previous government in regard to taxes which was based on this ABS definition. In light of this, why did you not provide this definition of a tax when I repeatedly asked for one during the estimates committees?
—Read the Hansard .

—Read the Hansard , very well. I was going to suggest that Senator Sherry might read the page after page after page of Hansard greens that we had on this matter. We went for hours on this subject in estimates.
—They were pink, but you were green.
—It has been 16 years since you were the member for Ballarat.
—Order!

—We went page after page and hour after hour on this subject in estimates. All I can say to Senator Sherry is that, after all that beating around the tree over and over again, you failed to understand. As a result of that, in two or three minutes I am not going to be able to change your view or your understanding of it. I might ask Senator Sherry, through you, Madam President, what he thinks a surcharge is.

—We certainly were not helped by your answer. Minister, why are you prepared to sacrifice any pretence as a credible economic spokesman merely to protect the government's credibility and its claims that it has not increased taxes or introduced new taxes when it clearly has?

—For Senator Sherry to talk about credibility on economic matters would have to be the greatest oxymoron of all time. I have nothing more to add to my previous answer or to the two hours, I think it was, that we spent on this in estimates.
—Order! I will call Senator Lees to ask the next question when there is sufficient silence for her to hear her name. Senator Lees.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment. This follows the question I asked yesterday about whether you believed wilderness areas could be mined and logged without affecting their wilderness values. You said mining was inconsistent with these wilderness values. So I ask: if you do believe that mining is inconsistent with wilderness values and that, as you said, wilderness areas should be preserved, will you now use all federal powers available to you to ensure that there is no mining in wilderness areas? Will you also rule out forestry and road construction in wilderness areas and work actively to see these things do not go ahead?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said yesterday is that I accept that wilderness is a conservation value that is important and should be preserved. I further said that I find it difficult to see how wilderness can be consistent with the activity of mining. I said that that was also the view of Senator Parer, who is as interested in preserving conservation values in this country as any other honourable senator.

ANSWER.PARA: In the case of forestry, wilderness assessments are taking place under the CRA process. It is our intention that wilderness areas be protected under the final regional forestry agreements as are negotiated between the Commonwealth and the states. It seems consistent with the view I have been putting to you, therefore, that mining in an area that has been preserved for its wilderness value would be inconsistent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I ask the minister about two specific areas: the D'Entrecasteaux National Park in Western Australia, where you do have the power to stop mining because you can simply refuse a mineral export licence, and in our home state of South Australia, the world's last remaining large area of undisturbed mallee wilderness—the Yumbarra Conservation Park, where the state government is now planning to allow mining exploration . Will you at least do all you can in your powers to stop both of those mining activities going ahead?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Western Australian one is being looked after by my very learned and able colleague—
—Who is that?
—Senator Campbell. I am sure that he will do all in his power to preserve wilderness values in that particular park.

ANSWER.PARA: The national park that you are referring to in South Australia currently prohibits mining. Therefore, I do not quite see the point of your question unless, of course, you are concerned about the deliberations taking place in the South Australian parliament. There is an issue as to whether that park should operate under the same basis as most national parks in South Australia, and that is a multi‐use park. I am not opposed to multi‐use, provided that the other use is consistent with the conservation values that we are seeking to preserve. That seems to me to be sound policy. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, did you actually make the remarks that were attributed to you recently that Australia's university vice-chancellors are running an ill-informed and misleading public debate over your budget cuts to education? Did you, in fact, say that universities `can't manage change' and are `afraid of the dark'? Do you stand by these comments? Are your views supported by the Prime Minister, or will he be convening another meeting of the vice-chancellors to repair the damage that you have caused?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you very much for that question, Senator. It gives me the opportunity to repeat what I said—albeit not in the same words, because I do not have the text of that speech here with me. Nonetheless, I can tell you that I stand by every word in that speech. For your information, and the information of others, let me just give you, in brief, what it said. It basically put the view, which I think should be shared by everybody here, that one of the things that universities and journalists have in common is a common interest in the search for truth. I do not think you could deny that.
—Unlike ministers.

—There is an interjection from Senator Carr, `Unlike ministers'. He must be speaking from experience of Labor ministers. Nonetheless, I simply made the point that the debate on higher education has been anything but a search for truth and anything but a spread of knowledge into the community. It has not, in fact, left the community properly informed about that which the government intends to do. If you, Senator, believe in a participatory democracy, you must believe that for voters to cast their vote it must be on the basis of what has actually happened: the truth. There is, therefore, a very strong interest in the truth being told.

ANSWER.PARA: What I said was that there were people in the higher education sector and others—and I include people on the other side in this bracket—who want to create the impression that we have cut $1.8 billion out of higher education. You know, Senator, that that is not true, but I have not heard you get up and tell your colleagues that they are misleading this chamber and they are misleading the Australian community.

The truth of the matter is that the real cuts to higher education are something in the vicinity of $689 million over four years, and that is against $20 billion in expenditure. I tried to make it very clear in that speech that I am happy to have a discussion about the need to make those savings. A one per cent cut against growth estimates next year is not something that universities will be unable to cope with. A three per cent cut the following year is a very small cut, compared with what some other portions of the community have had to bear.

I am happy to have a debate about whether it is right and proper that we shift to a differentiated HECS. I am happy for you to take the case that doctors should pay the same as teachers for an education which costs more and gives them more. If that is the position you want to take, that is entirely up to you. I am happy to have that debate. What I do not think does this place any credit, what does not do the higher education sector any credit, and what does not do any sections of the media that feed on this misunderstanding any credit, is to create the impression in the community that $1.8 billion is being taken out of higher education when that is simply not true. I further made the point in that speech, Senator—and you can give me a supplementary if you like; I would love one on this point—that there are plenty of—

TALK.START.PARA: —We can promise you that.
—Good. There are plenty of people in the community—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone, just a moment. There is far too much noise in the chamber.

—There are plenty of people in the community—75 per cent of school leavers—who do not get that opportunity. They like to think that those who do—who go through our higher education and who are now responsible for it—can see a way ahead, are not entirely dependent on the government and are prepared to continue the change process, which they have been undergoing for many years. But there is a reluctance on the part of some to accept that change is a continuing part of life, and this point needs to be understood: those who do not get the opportunity of higher education, who do not get the added rewards—the higher income and the better employment patterns—rely on those in higher education to know what to do. (Time expired)

—I am very pleased to ask a supplementary question, Minister. I remind you that you have not at all indicated, in response to the question that I did put to you, whether or not the Prime Minister actually agrees with your insulting remarks to the vice-chancellors. I ask you to respond to that. I also ask: how do you respond to the criticism from Professor Gavin Brown, the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Sydney, who said that it is `totally unhelpful' of you to `slag off' at universities without making any constructive efforts to help them improve?

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), to a question without notice asked by Senator Eggleston today, relating to proposed amendments to the Native Title Act.

The question of native title has been one of the most important matters which has been brought before this Senate since federation. In fact, it was in this chamber that there was, I think, the longest debate in this country's history on that bill. At the time, coalition senators said that this bill was unworkable and history has proved it to be so. In fact, we have in excess of 380 claims across Australia. Forty per cent of the continent is under claim, yet no native title has been found. Satisfaction has not been found by indigenous people, developers, pastoralists, miners or people in industry. In fact, to date I would put to the Senate that the bill has been a disaster.

With these amendments, the government is intending to make the bill workable. I say to fellow senators, the Australian community and, in particular, members of the press: beware of anyone who criticises these amendments as being racist, beware of anyone who uses labels in this argument, beware of people who seek to attack the person in this argument because that would signify that they have lost the argument themselves. Too many people in this debate would try to argue it on emotive terms.

We have to look at this bill in an analytical fashion. We have to make the bill work. We have to amend the process whereby justice is meted out to all and, most importantly, where results will be achieved. To date, there have been a lot of complaints from industry and Aboriginal communities that there has been too much delay, that this whole process has become bogged down. Time and time again, senators from both the opposition and the government have said that lawyers have been the only ones to benefit from this native title process. I would put it to the Senate that these amendments go a long way to streamlining the process to make it workable and to cut out the role of lawyers who have enjoyed the proceeds from this process thus far.

When one looks at the right to negotiate one will see that it is possible on one project to have several rights to negotiate. That is in no-one's interests. Therefore, the amendment which proposes that you have one right to negotiate in relation to a project as a whole is a thoroughly sensible one. The amendment which says that you can deal with native title processes as well as state approval processes for a development is a thoroughly sensible one. The situation at present is that you have to go through state processes and only after that embark on native title processes. That gives you a cumulative effect which can take years before any decision is made.

As has been said by members of the opposition and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), there is a lot to be said for economic development in remote areas for Aboriginal Australia. In areas where there have been developments not only in the tourist industry but also in the mining industry, we have seen that Aboriginal Australia has benefited. It is by this process of facilitating development and taking native title rights into account at the same time and on an even balance that you can see how this framework can possibly work.

There is one other aspect I would commend—that is, the question of voluntary agreements, which Senator Parer referred to. The question of voluntary agreements has been a vexed one. People have wanted to come to an agreement, but they have been unable to because the system will not let them have an agreement which can work with any efficacy or certainty. This proposal by the government will allow a voluntary agreement to be registered. I think that is a step in the right direction. Of course, it is a complicated area.

The amendments will have to deal with a rather complex proposal where people who want to form an agreement in relation to native title will come together. Nonetheless, this government has not shied away from addressing this most complex area, something which the former government shied away from completely. The only amendments we had were in relation to the High Court decision of Brandy, which was foist upon the former government.

This government is addressing this complex problem head-on. That is a courageous effort on behalf of the government. I compliment Senator Minchin on his excellent work and consultation, which I might say has been extensive. That is a lot more than we can say for the Native Title Bill. Senator Cooney would remember the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs had seven days and an air force jet to go around this vast continent and consult with the whole of the country as to the whole of the Native Title Bill. We have had, I would submit, consultation which would be at least tenfold higher than that, and that is just in relation to some amendments to the bill.

In other words, they are saying that the great white father, the federal minister for Aboriginal affairs, the protector of Aborigines—that is how the government sees Senator Herron; it is certainly how the Prime Minister sees him—can determine that they will receive significant benefits from the mine. Some Aboriginal people in Kakadu National Park have determined—they met with me last week as a matter of fact—that because of the disruption that is currently being caused out there, rightly or wrongly, in terms of their community, they do not want mining to proceed. That is their view as a community. They are the people who actually live and experience these things.

The federal minister for Aboriginal affairs in 1996 can overturn their decision in their interests. The minister for Aboriginal affairs can determine that they do in fact receive significant benefits from the mine. They do not know their own minds; they do not know what is best for them! He can put that aside. I could not believe this when I read it in the government's paper yesterday. It is legislated paternalism and it is utterly contemptible.

I say to Senator Minchin and Senator Ellison that I would predict safely—it is hard to predict things in here, as we all know, but I am prepared to take a punt on this—that whatever else might pass through the Senate, and a great deal of this no doubt will, this particular obnoxious provision that the minister for Aboriginal affairs can supplant the views of the Aboriginal people themselves as to what is in their interests will be, if nothing else, rejected by this chamber.

—The problem with the presentation that we have just heard was its total concern for certainty for the non-Aboriginal interests—certainty for the mining companies and certainty for the pastoralists. What about certainty for the Aboriginal community in this country? Don't they count?

—They are always out of the equation. It comes through in that sort of presentation. The people on the other side of the chamber do not even know what they are saying. BREAK.PARA: The minister for Aboriginal affairs is going to be able to dictate what is good for the Aboriginal community in this country. Isn't that a throwback, as Senator Collins says, to the protector for Aboriginal or native peoples status of the past?

And that is that.

I refer to this consultation process which the government is talking about. In six months they have got it right. In some months of consultation with the Australian indigenous community they know what is good for them. That is redolent of paternalism. That is redolent of misunderstanding. That just wreaks of you know what is good for the Aboriginal people above what they believe is good for themselves. TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done about it?

BREAK.PARA: Whose interests in the land are going to be supreme and arbitrated by the ministers of this government, including the minister for Aboriginal affairs? Will it be the Aboriginal interests? TALK.START.PARA: —What we have heard, especially from Senator Brown just now, is an indication that if you are unarmed with facts you can say anything just as long as it sounds good. BREAK.PARA: Why do you think we went to the people at the last election with a promise to amend the Native Title Act to make it more workable? TALK.START.PARA: —Of course they would be outraged.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know why they were outraged? Because there was no proper threshold test requiring that Aboriginal group to justify why they were bringing that claim. ANSWER.PARA: We heard evidence from other lawyers representing Aboriginal groups who agreed that an increased threshold test, for example, would get rid of vexatious claims and give credibility to the currency of native title. TALK.START.PARA: —If it had been, you would have been screaming your head off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins is interjecting, and he said to us that the Prime Minister had delivered on pastoral leases. ANSWER.PARA: It was clearly within our election promises to make the Native Title Act more workable. We want to see it work. TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make a few remarks in whatever time remains to this taking note of the answer in relation to native title. I do want to address my remarks to what Senator Bob Collins has said—and I am sorry that he has now left—because I do respect what Senator Bob Collins has to say on native title matters; I respect the experience he has on this. I do just want to say that I am sorry to hear that he thinks this is legislated paternalism, and I would be very glad to talk to him about his concerns with the particular provision we are referring to—that is, the power for the minister to intervene in relation to the right to negotiate process.

ANSWER.PARA: The amendment has been drafted to ensure that there is consideration of native titleholders' interests in the matter. So it was done very deliberately to ensure that the minister must take account of the interests of native titleholders when deciding whether or not to exercise the power proposed under that particular provision. I am therefore somewhat concerned by the remarks of Senator Collins, and I would like to talk to him about them. I would also remind him, of course, that the Labor Party in framing this bill did provide in section 42 for the minister to be able to override a determination made by the arbitrator, the tribunal, in order to allow a mining project to proceed.

All we are doing is taking and applying exactly the same principle that is already in the act—that is, the capacity for the minister to insert his or her own determination in relation to the question of whether a mine can proceed by simply allowing the minister to bring such an intervention forward in the process—being the principle that the Labor Party provided in the act when it drew it up in 1993. I think the hysteria that has been built up over this suggestion is really quite ridiculous.

I would also like to take the opportunity to stress that we have built these amendments very much on the principle of respecting the Racial Discrimination Act. We have gone out of our way to make sure that these amendments are not inconsistent with the Racial Discrimination Act. Nothing we have done in relation to our proposals on the right to negotiate would constitute any breach of the Racial Discrimination Act, nor is there anything in our amendments which breaches our fundamental commitment to respect the fact of native title where it has survived. In other words, we are not proposing, nor will we, any extinguishment of native title. Those are the two fundamental premises of our approach, and all these amendments respect those two commitments.

I also thank Senator Brown for his contribution, but I am also sorry that he thinks what we are doing is paternalistic. I would hope that is not the case. I would ask him to consider the fact that under this act, which has been in operation for three years, and in the four years since the Mabo decision, there has not been one determination that anybody, other than the Murray Islanders, has any native title. I think that is a very sad fact, and I think it is partly because of the incredible complexity and, frankly, unworkability of many parts of the Native Title Act.

Much of what we are proposing I think will lead to a situation where it will be easier for Aboriginal groups to be able to get a determination in their favour that they have native title, and I hope that that will be the outcome. But at the moment, claims are getting bogged down in the most extraordinary and expensive legalistic processes that we want to simplify. It is not all a one-way street. There are many respects in which we have taken on board and accepted propositions put to us by Aboriginal groups, particularly in relation to the amendments dealing with the representative bodies. Those amendments take on board many of the things put to us by Aboriginal groups.

The question of only allowing the registration of group claims is very much in response to Aboriginal positions put to us. It does not and will not prevent individual Aboriginals from making a claim to the Federal Court for a determination that they have native title. But in response to propositions put to us by Aboriginals, we are proposing that individual claims not be allowed to be registered for access to the right to negotiate—because, as Aboriginals keep reminding us, native title is really a communal title, a group title. Aboriginals are extremely concerned by the extent to which the act allows individual claims to be made with no group basis. So we have a situation of multiple overlapping and competing claims, particularly in the gold fields of Western Australia, that are seriously causing disharmony among Aboriginal communities.

So we are working with Aboriginals to try to overcome some of those problems caused by the current structures in the act. Also the voluntary agreements process, as referred to by Senator Ellison, is something that Aboriginals are looking for. In fact, it is one area where there is great unity of purpose among industry, state governments and Aboriginals to find a way in which voluntary agreements can be entered into and registered so that acts can occur on native title land with the agreement of Aboriginals and so those acts can be valid and for the benefit of Aboriginals.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Economic and Social Decline in Country Australia

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 9 October 1996, from Senator Woodley:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The continuing economic and social decline in country Australia, exacerbated by the 1996 budget cuts to funding for programs in rural and regional areas.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Woodley, I announce that I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concur rence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The continuing economic and social decline in country Australia, exacerbated by the 1996 budget cuts to funding for programs in rural and regional areas.

I have moved this motion today because I firmly believe that, unless the major parties and the rest of Australia wake up to the fact that rural Australia is in serious trouble, the bush will wither to such an extent that it will not recover. I firmly believe that the first budget of the Howard government, a National‐Liberal coalition, will hasten that decline, a sad indictment on the so‐called country party and a bitter irony for its supporters in the bush. Budget cuts affecting rural Australia have hit a wide range of programs, including assistance to agribusiness, regional development, drought relief, quarantine and inspection programs, education, the ABC and labour market programs.

Indirectly, rural Australia will be affected by changes to health funding which will discourage doctors from practising in country areas. They will be affected by the proposed partial privatisation of Telstra which will devastate work forces in country towns and they will be affected by Public Service cuts affecting almost every service provided by the federal government. The exact budget cuts include the gutting of regional development programs; the cutting of $20 million dollars from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service budget over the next two years; the freezing of programs of assistance for agribusiness administered by the Department of Primary Industries; and the savage cutting of $55 million from the ABC with the premier regional radio show Countrywide dropped from next year's schedule. I note that this puts the lie to the government's claim that ABC cuts will not hurt rural Australia.

Perhaps we can draw conclusions from this about the government's promise that privatising Telstra will not hurt rural people either. This government has failed to give farmers exemption from Austudy and Social Security assets test—despite the recommendations of several inquiries, some of which were chaired by National Party senators—and failed to give major cuts in allocations to drought assistance funding. We now have a primary industries minister who openly describes farmers as having a mendicant mentality—in other words, describing struggling farmers as beggars, dependent on handouts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did he say that?

—In the Australian . I have not got the date with me, but I will give it to you another time. The minister is a global free‐trader and is overseeing an administration that, in a few short months, has proposed that primary producers in this country will be exposed to massive risks by the proposed dropping of import bans on overseas salmon, chicken and apples.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the average Australian and the media does not see the country as a very important, cutting edge or sexy issue, but the former science writer for the Australian newspaper Julian Cribb recently showed just how cutting edge the issue of keeping the family on the farm is for this country and the world. Mr Cribb, in a paper given in Canberra last August, pointed out that in the new world order a state of war exists between the haves and the have nots. From Rwanda to Rio de Janeiro, the conflicts are triggered by the underlying causes of poverty and deprivation of key human needs—land, food and water. Who fills those basic human needs? Farmers of course—mendicants as the primary industry minister calls them.

If rural Australia is allowed to wither away by an economic rationalist government hell bent on survival of the fittest in an unfit world, those needs will no longer be filled by Australian farmers. We will have to feed our children imported food, no longer fresh and chemically treated. We could end up with the same nightmare scenario that exists today in the United States where every fruit and vegetable must be a certain size and colour to get passed by the food administration for sale and to arrive at that state every fruit and vegetable has to be chemically treated.

BREAK.PARA: I am not overstating the drastic crisis in the Australian bush but don't take my word for it. Take the word of farmers and regional leaders from around Australia who were interviewed for the Bulletin magazine's August feature on how the government is subjecting the bush to death by 1,000 cuts in the budget—the Bulletin's words.

In this report, the National Party's branch president in Manilla, near Tamworth, said, `People are very angry—it's crunch time for the National Party.' In the same article, a former National Party MP Tony Windsor accused the coalition of betraying the bush by sidelining country issues with patronising attitudes. Or you could take the word of the heads of all the major churches in Queensland who are seeking urgent talks with state and federal governments over the crisis in the bush.

Or take the word of the director of Lifeline in south west Queensland whose funding to counsel drought stricken farmers has been cut by a federal minister who seems to think the drought is over. Or take the word of grain growers spokesman Ian MacFarlane, who recently raised questions about whether farmers were better off under the coalition or the Keating Labor government. I think we know what he was thinking.

Last week a meeting of the rural community in Roma denounced the Howard government's record so far as the bush is concerned and accused National Party members of the government of not doing enough for people living in rural and regional Australia. This week a delegation of rural people to Canberra led by the president of the Queensland Farmers Federation will ask National Party back benchers to throw them a lifeline. I wonder if they will be heard.

Farmers and rural people are practically begging the government for a hearing and this government is showing them a clean set of heels. The major parties and the people of Australia ignore the decline of the bush at the peril of every citizen in this nation. The choice is clear: we can choose to support our regional communities with something like the support given to the defence industry in this country so the family can stay on the farm or we can let Australia's rural heart wither and die, watch displaced country people move to the already crowded urban coastal areas, adding to the number of jobless people and in turn this will push up crime rates—typical of areas of high development such as the Sunshine Coast in my own state of Queensland.

I implore the government, senators and the people of Australia to wake up to what is happening in regional Australia or we are in deep trouble. I close with the words of Martin Flanagan, a writer for the Age who writes regularly on rural affairs, in an article entitled `Economically rational mateship':
Mr Howard believes traditional Australian values are alive in the bush. They are in an agonised way.
But, for anyone who cared to look, the despair of people in the bush has been obvious for a decade or more, not least in the suicide rate among its young men.

Rural and urban Australia have probably never been more distant than they are at this time. While post-war migration has transformed our major cities, its effect on rural Australia has been relatively minor.
At the same time, the National Party, through its partnership with the Liberal Party, has gradually moved away from policies for which it was formed.

If there was one thing the old Country Party never doubted, it was the need for government intervention. In John Howard's youth, politicians such as `Black Jack' McEwen protected his people behind a wall of subsidies and tariffs, and there was a good argument that he was right to do so.
Thirty years later, there is a feeling among people in the country that they have been politically betrayed, combined with the sense that their identity is under threat.
And so it is. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Boswell has the call.

—Senator Woodley has accused this government of removing regional programs. SPEECH.PARA: The government has established a new regional affairs unit in the Department of Transport and Regional Development. That will take precedence over what we have had in the past. When it comes to drought relief—and I acknowledge Senator Bob Collins's contribution in this—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about mine?

—It was Senator Bob Collins who actually produced that. In no way has this government removed that; that is still in place. Yesterday the Queensland Farmers Federation came to Canberra. I did not see them beating a track to the Democrats' door.
—You do not hang around that door, Ron.

—No, I do not hang around that door. They came to the National Party for support because they know where their friends are—on this side of the house. There is a problem with drought relief payments and that is going to be a matter of discussion tonight at the National Party's specially called meeting.
—Can I come, Ron?
—No, you certainly won't be invited. We have listened today to a motion put in this Senate by Senator Woodley, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The continuing economic and social decline in country Australia, exacerbated by the 1996 budget cuts to funding for programs in rural and regional areas.

Let us just have a look at what the budget did for rural Australia. The isolated children's allowance was increased by $17 million. Senator Woodley did not acknowledge that. Let us be honest. You are a man of the cloth, you should acknowledge those things. If you are going to criticise, at least be fair about it and acknowledge some of the benefits.

Primary and secondary correspondence allowances have increased by $1,000 to $1,500 per annum. Even Senator Woodley acknowledges that the government got that right. The non-means tested basic boarding school allowance increased to 55 per cent of average boarding fees from $2,500 to nearly $3,000. That is another benefit for rural Australia. There is $123 million for RAS for 1996-97, an increase of $90 million.

Let us be reasonable, Senator Woodley. When you come into this chamber, you of all people—and I acknowledge your concern for farmers—should at least be honest and acknowledge where the government is giving and not just come in with a diatribe of absolute negativity. As I said, Senator Woodley, what you want, what you have got in your mind, what the Democrats want, is a government that will have the farmers totally relying on handouts. That is not what farmers want and that is not what they would even think about. That is totally in opposition to what a farmer wants.

Yes, there are needy farmers, as I have conceded, but there are wealthy farmers out there too. There are farmers who are doing it well. There are farmers providing millions and millions of dollars for overseas exports. There are hundreds and thousands of farmers, but there will always be some at the bottom end of the scale that do need help. We certainly acknowledge that and we are prepared to move in and help them.

BREAK.PARA: That is why there is a $90 million increase in RAS funding. The drought relief payments are holding on at the moment. I urge the government, and I will continue to urge the government, to extend those drought relief payments after the December cut-off period.

So today we have a motion that was borne out of a misconception of what the Democrats want to see for the Australian farmers. Unfortunately, Senator Woodley is totally wrong. The National Party have not walked away from the farming sector. The Liberal Party have not walked away from the farming sector. The people who are responsible for the absolute and utter disaster in the farming area are the people who extended the interest rates up to 23 per cent. If there is anything that devastated the farming industry, it was the 23‐plus per cent interest rates.

I might add, Senator Woodley, that you voted with that party over there when it was the government. You voted with them on an average of about 70 per cent of the time. So you are just as culpable as the Labor Party in this matter. So please do not come in here crying crocodile tears and putting up stupid motions that have no substance. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in this debate because it does give me a chance to put a couple of myths, which are busily being created by the federal minister, to bed. I have to make one brief reference to the contribution I just heard from Senator Boswell. One of the things that really amused me about the National Party reaction to the last budget was a doorstop that was done by the Leader of the National Party, Mr Fischer. —What do you think about that?

—Indeed, I know a lot of the backbench regional members were not too impressed, but it was a fair indication of where the National Party is these days. They claimed as their chief victory, protecting against the attacks from the Liberal Party, a program which the Labor Party retained in office for its whole 13 years, and that is pretty much where the National Party is these days.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting—Senator Woodley would agree with me on this—how the rhetoric changes when you change sides in parliament. When I was the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, I heard nothing but `fortress Australia' from Senator Boswell. It has all changed. The barriers are down now that they are in government. We can open it all up. I am delighted to hear him say that.

Senator Woodley mentioned the Lifeline service in Queensland that is providing desperately needed help to primary industry people who, I regret to say, are still in real distress in that state. Help is probably the best value for money that you can get. This tends to be the case with most federal money delivered to the responsible charities because of the huge amount of voluntary and unpaid effort that is put in to supplement it.

In terms of the real response to the budget, I do not think that that example can be improved upon. It is a simple story, but I think it encapsulates the new political attitude brought to the bush by this government. As a Labor Party member, I have to say that with some feeling of irony. It shows that a human element to national government was actually lost on 2 March.

I received an anxious phone call before the budget from the annual conference of the Queensland Graingrowers Association, which was held in Toowoomba. I was told that the Darling Downs and South West Regional Director of Lifeline, the Reverend Noel Parke, had made an impassioned plea to the 400 delegates at that conference for carry‐on funds to keep Lifeline's farm crisis counselling service afloat. Reverend Parke told the delegates that he had been informed by a senior officer of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy at the rural finance summit in Canberra `not to bother reapplying' for funding to maintain the farm crisis counselling service. As primary industries minister, I had arranged for funding for $105,000 to go to Lifeline in each of the past two years, after personal representations I had received from Reverend Parke and the Queensland Graingrowers Association. I was shocked at the federal government's apparent disregard for the basic welfare needs of these farming families, and the Howard government provided no cogent reason for its reluctance to provide this ongoing support for family services in southern Queensland.

The workload of the service is immense. The last of the money provided by us runs out at Christmas time. The current government confirmed during a Senate estimates hearing last week that its decision is final. That is what they said at Senate estimates in response to this matter when I pursued it. There is no money in this budget for the Lifeline service for drought affected farmers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—It is a shame, Senator West. It is contemptible. I do not actually raise this today to score a political point. I do so, as I said at the outset, to demonstrate a fundamental difference between this government and the last government in terms of the human dimension of the help that is being provided. I guess I also take the opportunity of raising it once again in the debate in a last‐ditch attempt to ask the government to change its mind and to provide funding, that only last week it said it would not, to this service to provide this desperately needed help to drought affected farmers in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of how valuable this help is—and I do not mind putting this on the record—the financial counsellors in adjoining services, the counsellors who actually work professionally, each voluntarily offered to give up a day's pay in order to have the money diverted to this service run by the Reverend Noel Parke and Lifeline. Of course, Reverend Parke declined that offer, but it was a genuine offer made by those financial counsellors to give up their own money in order to keep the service going.

BREAK.PARA: This is a service which this government has currently said it will not support. I take the opportunity of this debate to ask the government again to reconsider that decision and to provide the very small amount of money that the service so desperately needs to help these drought ravaged families in Queensland.

A string of National Party politicians ran a very public campaign last year when it was rumoured in the financial press that the former Labor government was planning to drop the diesel fuel rebate. It was, of course, not true. As usual, those fears proved to be absolutely groundless. At the time, as I said before, the National Party politicians all proclaimed that this was absolutely essential to ensure that farmers survived in Australia, so they claimed it as their chief victory in retaining it in the budget.

But the absolute irony of it—it seemed to be lost on Tim Fischer—was that the only people who were making an attack on it were his Liberal colleagues in the coalition and particularly, of course, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey).

In government we adopted a total systems approach to primary industry to build a viable and long‐term future for agriculture and to improve the economic and social fabric of rural areas. The integrated package of rural policy and programs in government was aimed at: improving farm profitability and international competitiveness, encouraging sustainable agricultural practices, and enhancing social and economic opportunities for rural communities. The focus was towards low levels of government support and a high degree of market responsiveness. Government assistance was primarily aimed at helping individuals and groups to identify their needs and to acquire the information, skills and resources necessary to apply practical solutions. This was done across all portfolios.

In the primary industries and energy portfolio we strived to ensure that it included every single stakeholder, and I think we did that successfully. From state governments to local governments to regional and community councils, I think we did make a very successful effort in regionalising these programs. It was, in fact, a concerted effort to help whole catchment areas and whole regions rather than it being help simply directed at individual farmers or groups of farmers.

In contrast, between the 1993 election and the March poll this year, the now Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Anderson, released one new opposition policy document for rural Australia. It was an internally inconsistent drought policy which would, if it were ever implemented as written—I hope it will not be—largely undo the national drought policy. Thankfully it has now been dropped.

During the campaign Mr Anderson released one policy document, Reviving the heartland, which I read as though I was looking into a mirror. It picked up every major policy platform that had been developed by Labor in government: for example, the much vaunted supermarket in Asia strategy. That strategy could not have been formulated if the Labor Party had not, in a policy sense, stocked the shelves with our food into Asia program, which this program simply replaces with a new name. All the major policies are still in place, although now at greatly reduced funding levels.

PARA.BREAK: What are not in place—as Senator West knows, as I know and as the coalition members who have been protesting, some of them publicly, know—are the thousands of public servants who have lost and will lose their jobs in government departments throughout small towns in rural and remote Australia. There is the closure of Medicare offices, the majority of them in regional Australia; the closure of tax offices throughout country areas in Australia; the closure of CES offices in country towns; the wind back of ABC services, which inevitably will hit the bush hardest; the complete closure of the entire department of regional affairs here in Canberra; and, I might add, the subsequent closure of the Office of Northern Development in Darwin. In terms of my own electorate, that office was absolutely crucial in getting major development projects such as the MacArthur River Mine and the Mount Todd Mine off the ground. They have all closed down with the consequent loss of people and their families from regional Aus tralia. These are all the initiatives of this government in office in terms of the contribution they are making to regional Australia.

BREAK.PARA: During a number of years as transport minister and then primary industry minister, I was belted up by every National Party politician in Australia about the fact that, according to them, we did not fund roads sufficiently in Australia. To my utter astonishment—members of the National Party should hang their heads in shame over this—in this budget there is a massive $620 million cut to road funding for the national highway system in Australia. Most of it, of course, is in regional Australia, not in Sydney and Melbourne. I could not believe that particular budget provision, but there it is: a reduction of $620 million.

Why do I mention that? We just heard Senator Boswell, with a straight face, talking about the sins and iniquities of the Labor Party, when in government, increasing fuel excise. Is he seriously suggesting by necessary inference that in government the coalition now proposes to reduce it? Of course not! But they have actually reduced the level of road funding under Labor by $620 million. Talk about a bunch of hypocrites! I have to say that this list goes on and on.

There is a lot of pain and most of it is being felt in regional Australia. This government fails to appreciate that many of the lost jobs—whether they be in the public or private sector—were providing absolutely vital off‐farm income to many rural families across Australia. In fact, it had become, in some places, almost an institutionalised additional income which kept those farms viable and the families on those farms. This budget absolutely and unarguably widens the gap between rural and remote Australia and the cities.

One of the most significant structural problems that Australia suffers from is that we are the most highly urbanised people on the face of the earth. There are 17 million of us in this huge island continent: 90 per cent of us live in half‐a‐dozen cities, most of them on the eastern seaboard. The federal government has got a major responsibility for doing everything it can to improve that situation and to reverse it, and yet we now have a brand‐ new coalition budget that, in fact, significantly widens that gap and worsens that problem.

To our utter astonishment—it is the first time I have ever seen this in print from a government in Canberra of any political persuasion—what did the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) say in justification for closing down the federal Department of Regional Development and closing down the funding for all the RDOs across Australia that were doing such significant work? Not all of them, of course, were successful, but have a look at what the mayors of the cities where some of them were operating said about the real on the ground support that they were giving to those townships—plenty of them were saying it. They were all closed down, but what was the federal minister's formal reason for doing so? To my utter astonishment he put out a press statement which said that the reason they closed down the Department of Regional Development was:
There is no clear rationale or constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement.
Where does that leave the National Party in the coalition, might I ask, rhetorically?

It is on the public record. It is an astonishing statement. He then went on to say in the press release, just in case you were in any doubt, that the responsibility for regional development firmly rested with state and local government. The federal government officially—from the minister—washed its hands of regional development in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Local government is not recognised in the constitution.

—No, of course it is not. But, Senator, as we all know—and some state governments and local government associations have already expressed this loudly and clearly—they are not in a financial position to fill that gap, a gap we had sufficiently funded to ensure that, in major policy terms, this major structural problem we suffer from in Australia of the wide gap between urban and rural Australia with most of us living in a small number of cities would not be widened. You can say whatever you like about the federal budget. No doubt there are some aspects of it that are positive. But the one thing about this federal budget and this astonishing policy statement on regional development, and the closure of the entire department, is that it unarguably will widen the already existing gap between urban and regional Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —As a rural Australian myself, I would be the first to acknowledge that rural Australia has done it tough in recent years. But I beg to differ from the words used by Senator Woodley in this urgency motion today. I beg to differ from his description of the decline in country Australia and prefer to term it rather, as Senator Boswell did, as the change in country Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes that we are talking about have been apparent for some years, with three key areas of concern: a declining population base; economic stagnation; and a sense that it is the poor relation to the major cities. These problems existed long before this government came to office and they are a reflection, if anything, on some of the policies and attitudes of the previous government to rural and regional Australia.

As well as the areas of concern that I have just mentioned, over the last 10 years we have had low or fluctuating commodity prices, between five and eight years of drought, and a drift of population to the cities. In some ways, this was attempted to be addressed by the regional development program that Senator Bob Collins has just referred to. He knows very well that two‐thirds of the funding for those programs was spent on the better cities program, that there were major problems in that program identified by the McKinsey, report such as that the program was poorly delivered, the highly bureaucratic reporting requirements and the excessive administrative burdens that were placed on RDOs under the programs. Not only that, the program was poorly conceived and RDOs had a limited success.

In contrast to this, Minister Sharp has announced that there will be brokering of major improved links between the regions and the investment and financing community, and given that the McKinsey report criticised the cargo cult mentality and the way in which the regions themselves had difficulty accessing investment and financial advice, this should go a long way before that. Senator Collins also said that we are putting no more money into it. He knows very well that one of the budget items this year was an additional $10 million over the next two years to complete already existing programs.

I move on to the way in which this government has started to address the problems of rural and regional Australia. Apart from the $1 billion family tax initiative which will give families more choice about work and parenting, there is, as Senator Collins did not remark on, a new $149 million road safety black spot program to improve roads, 50 per cent of which will be spent on rural roads. The road toll for 1995 was 2,017 people and road trauma costs Australia $6 billion annually. Anything that can move against this will be an improvement.

Senator Collins also spoke expressively about the supermarket to Asia program and the way in which our initiatives were a development of the previous government. The major difference that he did not talk about was that our micro‐economic reforms in transport and industrial relations will act so that we can at least deliver more efficiently and cheaply food to Asia in a way that the previous government never did. There have been many horror stories of perishable cargoes left to rot on wharves while unions went on strike and the previous government could not bring its much vaunted industrial relations program to bear on that so that we were at least able to deliver our exports. Therefore, we gained an extremely bad reputation in Asia for not delivering on time and not delivering our contracts. One of the major initiatives of our whole economic program will be to work in concert with the supermarket to Asia program so that at least we can gain a record as an efficient exporter and one who delivers cargoes on time.

Supermarket to Asia is going to look at the development of streamlined national food safety and residue regulations where there is considerable scope for reform and reducing the cost of regulation in the food industry— something that the previous government was not prepared to consider.

Need I point out in this budget the additional $49 million to accelerate regional forest agreements. There has been a new woodchip export licensing system which will allow for an additional one million tonnes of woodchips to be sourced from sawmill residues. Need I contrast that with the forest agreements of the previous government which never even got off the ground!

We have restored CSIRO funding. We have made a $90 million extension of drought assistance. There has been a four per cent increase in local government grants. There has been an integrated shopfront set up for services provided by the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs.

The Kelty report put out by the previous government considered many of the regions in Victoria as far as their export potential and the way in which they could improve their employment and productivity are concerned. Two of those are the Barwon‐Camperdown region and the Goulburn Valley region, both of which are poised to take advantage of the food technology initiatives which will be set up by the supermarket to Asia program, and that is something that I, as a Victorian, would be particularly pleased to see.

One of the deficiencies identified by the Goulburn Valley area was the lack of undergraduate places at universities to enhance the tertiary skills of those young people living in that region. As Minister Vanstone has announced that with the university reforms there will be 6,000 new undergraduate places next year, I can only imagine that this will bring great joy to the Goulburn Valley.

Lastly, like Senator Boswell, I would particularly like to point out the sheer hypocrisy of the Australian Democrats in bringing this matter of urgency to the Senate. For instance, not only do the Democrats advocate death duties, which would knock the inheritance of family farms right out of the economic spectrum; they have also declared themselves against the live sheep trade which underpins domestic sheep prices. They have always advocated ridiculous, to‐the‐extreme‐ left environmental ideas rather than looking for a combination of environment and sustainable farming activity.
The most recent demonstration of this was, I regret to say, Senator Allison's maiden speech, during which she painted farmers as environmental vandals. She said:
Farmers have pushed their land to the limit already in order to be competitive. Many have gone over that limit with disastrous consequences.

And she went on. For this Democrat senator to be representing herself as a senator for Victoria, where she must represent everyone, is totally reprehensible. I put to the Senate that this exposes the hypocrisy of the Democrats in putting such a motion before the Senate, and I ask the Senate not to carry this motion.
