TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to participate in this debate today because we have seen, particularly since the budget, an exacerbation of the problems that rural and regional Australia is facing. The problems are beginning to be felt out there, and I can understand the sensitivities that are being expressed by those opposite on the conservative benches. I have local newspaper clippings six inches deep on my desk, all drawing attention to the failings of the current federal government to look after regional and rural Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The one I quote is an excerpt from the Daily Liberal of 3 October which reports on a Newspoll of last week revealing the anger at the cuts of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). It says:

The federal government's strong lead in the opinion polls has slipped since the August budget, with dissatisfaction for Prime Minister John Howard rising sharply in rural areas . . . The largest jumps in disapproval for Mr Howard were among voters from rural areas (up 14 per cent) and from Queensland (up 13 per cent).

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—You are right, Senator Hogg, it is a shameful thing, but at least people who live in rural areas are beginning to be aware of what is happening and what is being done to them by this government. The budget betrayed the bush. There is no other way to describe it. It was one of the most damaging budgets to rural and remote areas in decades. The government's claim that it has improved the lot of those in the bush is nonsense. The impact of these cuts will be long term and far reaching.

SPEECH.PARA: The government—the Howard-Fischer government—gave a hint of what it would do when it abolished the regional development program of the former Labor government before the budget. It did not reduce its funding as the report of the National Commission of Audit suggested. No, it went even further. It abolished the program altogether.

When I asked during estimates why the transport and regional development title was still being retained after the government had abolished regional development, I was told that that was not correct. I suppose, technically, it is not. They only had a staff of 220; they now only have a staff of six, which reports to the transport economics area—not to any other operative area in the department. One has to wonder what this group of six people is going to be able to do.

Senator Collins has very clearly outlined what the impact of the abolition of regional organisations is going to be. I know very well. I was in Dubbo the day the announcement of the abolition of the department took place. I know very well the palpable anger that was being felt by that community, because that community was benefiting from a $2 million grant under this program for which it had been able to leverage over $40 million from AGL for the construction of a natural gas pipeline from Marsden to Dubbo and beyond if the RDOs had continued to be funded to the proper extent. They were very uncertain on that day—at that early time in the morning—as to whether their contract was going to be honoured or not. Fortunately, they were one of the organisations who had the two signatures on the contracts, and the cheques have been paid. They also have received $200,000 to set up a white cypress mill in Gilgandra.

The benefit to these communities is untold. The benefit of bringing natural gas to the Orana region of New South Wales means that industry will be attracted there—private industry will be attracted there—and that will, therefore, set up further jobs and further development for the region. But what does this current government do? It has abolished it completely. This is the government that says it cares about business and cares about industry. You would not think so by its actions. Its actions speak far louder than its words.

One of the other things that it has done is make massive cuts to labour market programs—a cut of $1.5 billion over the next four years—and that is going impact extremely heavily on rural areas. It has introduced cuts to skillshare, cuts to the LEAP program and cuts to new work opportunities. These programs have not just been providing employment for people but they have been providing these people with training and with skills. If we are going to be a caring community and offer our community the best chance available to them as the economy improves and as jobs become more prevalent, then we have to have an educated and trained community. But not this government! It does not care.

Another cut that we saw in the budget that will be particularly harmful to rural areas was a $620 million cut to the national highway system. How long before they fix the rest of the bridges between Narrabri and Moree? How long before a bypass can be ready for Moree? How long before Coonabarabran can have a bypass? These are road safety issues. It was fine for Senator Troeth to talk about some money that went to black spots—what was it; $149 million? What about preventing major problems by maintaining expenditure to the national highway system.

They have cut $620 million out of that and replaced it with a piddling $149 million. It just does not add up. Moree, Dubbo, Narrabri, Coonabarabran, Gilgandra—all of those places on the Newell Highway, which is one of the national highways—will in fact be not able to continue with the plans they had under way for bypasses.

There is $30 million cut from National Rail; $200 million cut from Landcare; $170 million cut from child care; $570 million cut from aged services; $55 million cut each year for the next four years from the ABC; and $1.8 billion cut from higher education. This is a government that cares about the bush? Don't give me such garbage! It is obvious that these cuts are going to impact on all of Australia, but particularly on rural areas.

The cuts to the ABC will be extremely hurtful because the ABC fulfils a very important role in country areas. It is not just entertainment; it is information. It is stock market information and expert advice and information to rural primary producers. But that is of course going to be cut.

The cuts to higher education are going to have a massive effect, as will the increase in the HECS fees for university students and the tiering of those fees. The other stupid thing they have done is put agriculture into the second tier of payments, which will mean that fewer farmers will choose to educate their children or themselves. The Labor government worked for years to improve agricultural education for farmers and to help them both economically, through more efficient practices, and environmentally, through teaching new farming techniques that limit the harm done to their land.

The higher education cuts will affect all students, as well as the universities themselves. Fewer country people will have an opportunity to receive higher education, which not only assists them with their careers but also plays an important role in the social development of our young people and communities. There are a number of rural and regional universities out there. One of the government senators has a bright idea. Senator Tierney is quoted in the Northern Daily Leader of 5 October as saying:
Rural universities should look towards supplementing their revenue by courting the overseas student market—
He said:
The University of Central Queensland which has a campus in Sydney for full paying overseas students is a good example of this model working.

It just makes you wonder what world they are living in. It is important to note that there have been a number of programs that have been axed. An article in the Daily Liberal of 3 October states that Mr Ossie Cruse, the state Aboriginal Lands Council chairman, believes cuts to government spending on Aborigines will have a `devastating effect' on communities throughout New South Wales. The article states:
Mr Cruse said all Aboriginal organisations would feel the effects of ATSIC's budget cuts.
He said Aborigines were already turning to the NSWALC for both funding and guidance as job cuts were confirmed in Aboriginal communities.

This government's actions are going to impact upon the actions and the lifestyle of people outside. I will finish with an editorial from the Central Western Daily of Orange of 5 October entitled `Federal Nats still asleep'. It reads:
Feedback from primary industries indicates that the Orange farm sector is expecting a favourable result from its campaign against the importation of New Zealand apples.
A broadranging rebellion against a likely Federal Government move to drop its import ban has been taking place—
But not yet the politicians you'd expect to sit up first.
It is amazing that once again this year, we are witnessing extreme disinterest by the Federal Nationals on a boilover issue in Orange primary industry.
It was only in July that the Federal Nationals were playing politics with farmers over the future of the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

And it was only last week that the Inland Marketing Corporation, and the aspirations of Central West farmers, received gut-wrenching news that the Federal Government has given promised research funding to Canberra airport instead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am cognisant of the fact that Senator Ferris is waiting to make her first speech today, so I will keep my remaining remarks as brief as possible. In the course of the debate, before we ran out of time, I was saying that in the last five weeks I have visited and spoken to Aboriginal representatives in Darwin, Jabiru, Alice Springs, Uluru and Denmark in Western Australia—not by phone but in person.

SPEECH.PARA: I was rather disappointed that in the debate some members opposite yelled out, `Ah, but you didn't get out of the bus.' It is really interesting that in a number of instances today the behaviour, inappropriate behaviour, of ministers was mentioned. That was relating to a dorothy dix question which was intended to give the impression that I—and it was said to the media—had wasted taxpayers' money. It was quite interesting that this was the response in today's debate.

It would be extremely difficult to spend a day having meetings and briefings at Ranger Uranium Mine without being out of a bus. That has never been acknowledged by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron).

So, if we are talking about ministerial responsibility and behaviour, it is about time that that bad behaviour was addressed and it was acknowledged that I did not conduct a sit‐in, that I was out of the bus all day and that the only time during that trip to Ranger that I was still in the bus was when we were in the bottom of the pit and places like that. I think that I am entitled to make a decision to stay in the four‐wheel drive for the few minutes or not. The four‐wheel drive had to be decontaminated later.

We are talking about accountability. Accountability to whom? I am hearing from Aboriginal communities that spending on Aboriginal programs ought to be accountable to Aboriginal people. But we have not heard that from the minister. We have not heard from this minister that he understands that Aboriginal communities are saying that spending on Aboriginal programs should be accountable to Aboriginal people and communities.

Point No. 1 of the motion relates to the failure of the minister to seek advice or consult before illegally imposing an independent auditor on ATSIC. People were giving scores in that particular debate. I would have to say that the score on that ruling quite clearly was 3‐0 in relation to the illegality of that action.

Point 2, seeking to make changes to eligibility criteria: yes, in the debate that was changed. We knew that. We went into that debate knowing that it needed to be changed. But I am talking about the responsibility of the minister to go into a debate on legislation on something that could well have cost ATSIC $4.7 million to repair a ministerial error.

BREAK.PARA: Many people in the Australian community cannot comprehend why this minister cannot understand the impact of his decisions. I was challenged during the debate to go with the minister when he visits a community. I have to say that I am covering all areas of the portfolio for Western Australia. But, if the minister is listening, I am happy to take the minister up on his challenge. Sure, you name the time. Provided that the Senate is not sitting and that I can make the time available without having other commitments, I am happy to accompany you on a visit to communities to listen to their responses to the changes that are occurring in the communities. Just let me know when that is to occur.

There are many reasons why it was necessary to have this debate today, not the least of which has been to show that some people do understand and have thought through the issues that are being promoted and have surfaced in the media in recent times. They do understand why the populist trend to find people to blame is a political godsend to the coalition; why it is helping them in their ratings. People do not understand what the bases are for the changes that have occurred that are making their lives less secure at the moment.

But this is not just occurring in Australia. If you look at a number of countries in recent times, with the change to economic rationalism the turmoils are often internal. So it is not just in Australia where scapegoatism has become a more obvious element of society. I would like to think that we can recognise the danger of scapegoatism before it reaches the levels to which we have seen it develop in other countries where, because of economic rationalist policies, because of such things as structural adjustment and major changes and differences between the rich and poor in those societies, there has been social turmoil and scapegoatism. I would like to think that, as mature people and as people representing the community in Australia, we recognise the dangers of scapegoatism and address them before they get to that stage in Australia; that, before they get worse, we will address them and start dealing with the issues of why people are feeling disenchanted, why there is a growing number of working poor, why the nature of jobs and employment is changing, and why it is easy to look at other people who appear to be getting handouts and assume that they are on a good wicket, when it is not the case.

Senator Bob Collins has very articulately pointed out the issues in relation to health, particularly health funding. I hope this debate about health and education service funding, but most particularly in the areas of self-determination, does get somewhere; that, if nothing else, the course of this debate today means that those issues will be recognised, that it will be seen that members of the community recognise it and are prepared to pull this into the debate that we are having today.

Today I was saddened to hear the minister pulling in the politically correct notion. That has been an excuse on a lot of occasions recently for parliamentarians not taking their responsibilities seriously and instead finding scapegoats in the community, targeting minority groups and those people who are less able to fight for their rights, less able to be represented in the parliament. It is our responsibility to try to represent not just the strongest in the community but all of the community where we can.

There are statistics of Aboriginal deaths in custody which show that, despite what anybody says in relation to so-called benefits, a large number of Aboriginal people who have died in custody were directly involved with the stolen generation—and not just that generation, but also the next generation whose lives become dysfunctional because their parents' lives became dysfunctional. It did not just happen 60 years ago; its repercussions are being felt today.

I do commend this motion to the Senate. But, no matter what happens, I am extremely grateful that the debate has occurred and that these issues at least are being put in the public arena. I hope that some of these issues will be dealt with, and that people will realise that there are ministerial responsibilities which do mean that you often have to check. I hope, if nothing else, there is an immediate remembering that, if there are going to be major changes, you check to find out whether they are even constitutionally possible and what their impact will be, before jumping in and making changes that will have major impacts on communities, especially communities which are already deeply disadvantaged in Australian society. I commend this motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —May I use this first opportunity I have had to speak in this place to add my congratulations upon your appointment. Fellow South Australians are proud of your achievement.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an honour to take my place in the Senate, which our constitutional authors determined at the time of Federation should be a protector of the rights of our states and, in particular, the rights of the less populous states. In choosing to follow the style of the American Senate by providing equal representation for each state, Australia is regarded as having one of the most powerful upper houses in the world.

As senators, we are part of an auspicious history. The original Senate was of course the highest deliberative body in ancient Rome, taking its name from the Latin senatus—literally, a group of elders. Clearly not all of us would qualify by their election criteria.

I had the chance to reflect on the history of the first Senate when I wandered among the spectacular ruins of the Forum and the Palatine Hill last year. These huge and imposing structures which still dominate the city are ongoing evidence of the civic pride, the engineering brilliance and the majestic grandeur of the old imperial city—and among those ancient pieces of marble and granite, an ongoing reminder of the fragility of democracy.

The state of South Australia, which I have the honour to represent, includes some of Australia's most diverse and beautiful landscapes, providing the backdrop for the resource industries which have become part of our nation's colourful history. The opportunities to create wealth for Australia and employment for its people were recognised soon after our state was first colonised.
In June 1836, the first edition of the South Australian gazette and Colonial Register reported an early description by Captain Charles Sturt, who wrote:
My eye never fell on a country of more promising aspect or more favourable position, than that which occupies the space between Lake Alexandrina and the ranges of the St Vincent gulf.

Of course the chances for prosperity offered to our early pioneers extended much further than the Adelaide plains. Our state's early wealth resulted from the determination and perseverance of our primary producers—those courageous and visionary men and women who pioneered our pastoral lands, establishing the great sheep stations which contribute to our wealth and our export income.
Their lives and their lifestyle in the harsh and often unforgiving bush attracted comment from a range of visiting international writers, among them Anthony Trollope, who observed in 1873:

The number of sheep at these stations will generally indicate with fair accuracy the mode of life at the head station: a hundred thousand sheep and upwards require a professional man‐cook and butler to look after them; forty thousand sheep cannot be shorn without a piano; twenty thousand is the lowest number that renders napkins at dinner imperative.

Maintaining standards and more than a modicum of commonsense in the face of testing adversity is a proud tradition in country families. It still remains strong and long may it continue. Their personal contribution and those of their industries built the strong foundations of this great country. We in the cities continue to enjoy the benefits that flow from their bountiful harvests and offer them support when the elements do not.

These great industries have given South Australia a good share of heroes, courageous Australians whose personal contribution continues to be remembered. Sidney Kidman, from a humble stockman's family, out of school and working at the age of 13, sacked when he asked for a pay rise, through ingenuity and sheer hard work became the largest land‐holder in the British Empire. In 1921, Kidman was knighted, not for his contribution to the pastoral industry but for his wartime efforts in supplying horses and equipment, fighter planes, ambulances and shipments of beef and wool for the First World War. Thomas Elder, and his brother‐in‐law Robert Barr Smith, who together built one of the largest pastoral agencies in the world, provided hundreds of jobs and rural services to the farming industries around Australia.

Pastoralists were of course not the only farming pioneers. Miners and early explorers found our first significant mineral wealth as South Australia was facing financial ruin. The early discovery of large copper deposits at Kapunda in 1842 and at Burra three years later saved the young colony from certain bankruptcy.

These industries also fostered some very special South Australians. Essington Lewis, from humble beginnings in the mining town of Burra, rose to lead Australia's largest company—Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. Douglas Mawson, a renowned geologist and engineer, is appropriately remembered for his pioneering spirit and incredible courage in adversity on the Antarctic coastline.

Minerals and resource processing industries have continued to contribute to the wealth of South Australia. We have in our state Australia's largest onshore oil and gas reserves in the Cooper Basin. We produce 60 per cent of the world's precious opal. There is in our starkly beautiful outback a world‐class 200-year-old resource of copper, silver, gold and uranium at Olympic Dam, while the world's largest zinc smelter is at Port Pirie.

For almost a century, iron ore has been mined in the Middleback ranges to be processed at Whyalla and, of course, we have our significant coal reserves at Leigh Creek. The $20 million South Australian exploration initiative is now uncovering many more of the prosperous geological secrets that have remained hidden beneath our ancient soils. Greater resource wealth seems assured.

BREAK.PARA: Our primary producers, blessed with a bumper season last year and optimistic that another could be at hand, boosted exports of their products last year to almost three‐quarters of a billion dollars—an increase of more than 200 per cent. The state's winemakers recently toasted overseas sales of $315 million—up by a quarter on last year and more than 400 per cent higher than five years ago.

Spectacular growth has also occurred in our manufactured exports. Our two motor car manufacturers are now producing 150,000 vehicles a year and they are selling their products to the world, creating new opportunities for expansion and jobs for more than 13,000 South Australians. During the past year, the vehicle and components industry exported products worth $254 million—double the figures of five years ago.

Last year South Australia's exporting industry sold to the world products worth more than $4.5 billion—clear evidence that we have at last conquered our old rustbelt image. But South Australia is not just a state of billion-dollar businesses. Our smaller but equally important niche market industries are supplying the gourmet picnic baskets of the nation.

We have first-class speciality food—fruit from the Riverland; tuna, oysters, lobsters and marron from our growing aquaculture industries of Port Lincoln, the Eyre Peninsula, Kangaroo Island, the southern coastline and Gulf St Vincent; our lean beef and lamb from the lush pastures of the south-east; and rich grain products from the state's farming lands, which are widely sought after around the country. And, at last, the great restaurants of the world are discovering our fine wines.

I am very proud of my state of South Australia, although my pathway to this place has also taken me through other states and territories. I first came to the national capital as a young journalist to work at the Canberra Times and soon became an enthusiastic spectator of the national political scene. Canberra was then a robust and developing city, growing by more than 10 per cent a year. As the new suburbs tumbled over the grazing lands and the foothills of Woden and Belconnen, the dust storms from the newly created cul‐de‐sacs and playing fields filled the houses—and the eyes—of the residents.

What a spectacularly beautiful city Canberra has become—its avenues of stately trees and sweeping vistas a living tribute to the imagination of Walter Burley Griffin and his talented wife Marion whose significant contribution to her husband's work must surely soon be recognised in this national capital.

During my days as a Canberra journalist I was privileged to meet Australia's first female federal member of parliament and later cabinet minister, Dame Enid Lyons, who was in Canberra to officially open a school in a suburb which bears her family's name. She was a modest, yet quietly inspiring woman, her forthright and commonsense approach to politics a lesson for us all. Dame Enid, writing in her first book, So we take comfort, likened her entry as the first Liberal woman into federal politics as being, `like a lamb to the slaughter, like a sheep before the shearers, I was led forth to have a go.'

Many other women followed, including South Australia's Dame Nancy Buttfield, who became the fifth woman to enter the Senate, serving our state with distinguished representation for a total of 16 years. Today there are five women among South Australia's 12 senators and there are 23 women in the Senate—the highest number ever. Together with the 22 female members of the House of Representatives, women are now, on merit, clearly taking their place as elected representatives of their communities.

The state I represent of course led the way when, as Helen Jones has written, `On a hot December morning in 1894, a week before Christmas, the South Australian House of Assembly resounded to loud cheering as the parliament acknowledged its decision to give votes for women.' The youngest Australian colony was the first not only to give women the vote but also to allow them to stand for parliament.

PARA.BREAK: I particularly mention the efforts of Catherine Helen Spence, a courageous campaigner and social reformer—and a journalist by profession—who stood, unsuccessfully, for selection as a representative of South Austral ia at the Federal Convention of 1897. Her personal commitment to the care of women and children, and their education and personal development has been well recognised by grateful generations who have followed.

BREAK.PARA: South Australian women have continued in more recent times to make this special mark at a national level. Dame Roma Mitchell, who recently retired as South Australia's first female state governor, has been an inspiration to generations of women as she, with brilliance yet quiet modesty, blazed a trail across the legal pathways of Australia.

My own entry to national politics followed valuable experience as a member of staff both in federal parliament and with the South Australian state Liberal government. I worked for several years as a lobbyist here in Canberra as a member of a quite special team of people at the National Farmers Federation. A unique combination of commonsense and courage, together with great leadership, delivered some very important national milestones.

No-one in Canberra on that crisp winter's day will ever forget the 45,000 farmers and their families who gathered on 1 July 1985 outside Old Parliament House to make their own peaceful and well‐mannered protest about the effect of interest rates and spiralling farm costs. There were no bills for damage on that day, no riot shields were required, no shops were looted and certainly no injuries were inflicted on our police. That special day, when the farmers came to town, must surely be Canberra's most successful political rally.

As a resident of Canberra during the early eighties, I watched with some awe the construction of this great white House on the Hill. With my two sons, I came to the top of Capital Hill the day before the road closed to begin the construction of the new building. Two rabbits and a large red kangaroo, early inhabitants of the hill, scuttled across our pathway through the grass and scrub on that day—a reminder that this was once considered the Bush Capital.

During those early years of construction, when the building was taking shape and we were offered periodical chances to visit, I often picked my way carefully through the cavernous spaces lit only with occasional hanging light globes. On one occasion, I sat on some of the concrete shapes that have now become this great chamber.

South Australia's magnificent Imperial Black granite from the Black Hill quarries, north east of Adelaide, is well represented in this national parliament. It is in the forecourt, it paves the public foyer, and a single piece now forms the reflective pool in the Members' Hall. But most importantly, it is South Australia's Imperial Black granite which paves the area beneath the massive flagpole from which flies our great Australian flag.

The construction of this new parliament building offered me a special time for reflection and an opportunity to consider what kind of Australia those men and women elected to this place would frame for my children's grandchildren, to wonder what effect their decisions would have on future generations each time they passed—or failed to pass—the myriad of legislation crucial to our nation's future, and to consider whether, as teenagers in another half a century, my great grandchildren will face the future with optimism or despair.

My own musty teenage diaries reveal—amongst the tittle and tattle of daily school life and study, the trials of learning to drive and the warnings over curfews disobeyed—an overwhelming optimism which leaps from almost every scribbled page. There is a clear sense of hope and the sure knowledge that not only was there a choice of careers but that work would certainly follow—and the chance to walk home in safety from the Friday night dance.

Our task here—not only as elected men and women but also mostly as mothers and fathers, and some as grandparents—is to take on the task of restoring this sense of hope and optimism to all of our young people. We have the awesome responsibility, for example, of turning around the ever-increasing rates of youth suicide, which results in more than 400 of our youngsters taking their own lives before their 25th birthday, leaving families and friends who never fully recover.

In this bountiful country of ours, how can it be that on every day of every year one of our young men or young women is making that fateful decision? It is the responsibility of each one of us to uncover the reasons for this national tragedy. We simply must work together to make the policy changes that will restore hope to these young people and give them back the sense of optimism and purpose that they so desperately seek.

I consider myself very fortunate to have come to this Senate at a time when hundreds of thousands of Australians have decided to make a fundamental change in the way our nation is governed. They voted overwhelmingly for a new approach to our national government, to turn Australia around. They chose a Prime Minister and a government that would deliver this fresh policy approach.

They want us to unravel the myriad of regulations that were part of an old‐fashioned and paternalistic society. Freedom of choice—so that men and women themselves, not government, make the decisions that affect their daily lives—is what binds a thriving society.

Madam President, I look forward to speaking in debates and voting for those policies that will bring a fresh approach to our great country, to restore the sense of hope that people are so desperately seeking. I thank the Liberal Party and all my South Australian supporters for giving me this opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

SPEECH.PARA: That the following regulations be disallowed:
Regulation 3 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 187 and made under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.
Regulations 3 and 7 of the Bankruptcy Rules (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 191 and made under the Bankruptcy Act 1966.
Regulation 3 of the Family Law Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 188 and made under the Family Law Act 1975.
Regulations 3, 4, 5, 6, 8 and 9 of the Federal Court of Australia Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 189 and made under the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976.
Regulations 3, 4, 5 and 7 of the High Court of Australia (Fees) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 190 and made under the Judiciary Act 1903.
Regulation 3 of the National Native Title Tribunal Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 186 and made under the Native Title Act 1993.
There is a very strong and firm starting point for this debate, and I would like to start with a quotation from an eminent legal person. It goes along the lines:

Where a person has a legal right to enforce or a legal defence to offer to another's claim, the imposition of substantial fees restricting access to the courts of law may place that person, unless he be affluent, outside the law's protection. In a society governed by the law no barrier can be erected against reasonable access to the courts for the vindication and protection of legal rights. To ensure that litigation is not frivolously commenced, modest fees have traditionally been exacted but the court has reserved a dispensing discretion to ensure that, where litigation can be seen to be justifiable, poverty is no bar to the operation of the law.

These are not just the words of any person or any jurist; they are, in fact, the words of the man at the pinnacle of the legal profession in this country: Chief Justice of the High Court, the Hon. Sir Gerard Brennan. They were included in the 1989 judgment in the matter of Citizen Limbo. It set out the principles on which court and tribunal fees should be based.

These were the principles that motivated the previous government when we developed the 1994 Access to justice and the Justice Statement in response to that report. In fact, in a sense they could be claimed to be the sentiments that motivated the current government's policy in this area before the election. Before the election they promised:
We make a commitment to keep a continual focus on the problems at hand—the achievement of a justice system that is accessible to all Australians, regardless of their means.

The measure that we have before us today is not just any disallowance measure. It is a measure which, as Chief Justice Brennan reflected in his judgment, goes fundamentally to the matter of Citizen Limbo. It goes very much to the core of our democratic system, it goes to the question of access to the courts, it goes to the question of access to rights and, consequently, it goes to the question of the relevance of laws made by this parliament to the citizens of this country.

We are debating, in fact, a disallowance motion which, if it is not carried, will see the continued implementation of massive increases in court fees—fees that will deprive not just tens of thousands but probably many more Australians access to a justice system. It will not be the very poor that will be denied access to justice by this measure; they are protected by the fee waiver provisions and the exemption provisions already in place. Nor will the rich suffer. For them fees represent no barrier at all. Those who will be denied justice as a result of these fees will be the ordinary middle Australians—the very people the Access to justice report targeted as being unable to access our justice system. They are the people, in fact, that the Access to justice statement tried to assist through the justice system.

We do not have here just a breach of promise by the government in terms of court fees and charges proposed to be levied by these regulations, but one that goes to the rights of citizens in this society. In moving in this direction I must say that not only has the government breached a promise and betrayed the access to justice system, they have also put themselves at direct war footing with the courts of this country. If one looks at a recent speech to the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration by the Chief Justice of Australia, one finds the following words:

The settlement of disputes by legal process is a fundamental function of government in a society under the rule of law. If the function is not performed, the law is not applied and the festering sore of injustice spreads the infection of self‐help. Power is then unrestrained by law. Peace and order are at risk and, sometimes, tragedy may be the consequence. Laws that are put on the statute book mock the integrity of the political process unless the beneficiaries of those laws can enforce them.
There cannot be a clearer statement from the highest ranking judge in this country in terms of the importance of access to the judicial system.

These measures proposed by the government in their budget of betrayal deny so many Australians access to the judicial system. We are talking about raising some $72 million from the Family Court system with these measures—a system which is there to assist families in times of crisis. What does this government want to do? It wants to rip $72 million off litigants in that system over four years. It also wants to take some $32 million from other litigants in the Federal Court system. For instance, your average small business claim will rise from just over $1,100 to over $12,000. The cost of enforcing a medium sized debt through bankruptcy proceedings will rise from $730 or so to at least $1,600 for an individual and over $3,000 for a company. A typical disputed family law claim will rise from $368 to over $2,000. An unlawful dismissal claim, which currently can be lodged free, will cost the applicants more than $2,700—and that is before one has to consider paying one's lawyers.

These are the fees you pay to the government to actually get into court—to have one morning in court. That is before you pay for your lawyers. Individually, these fees are harsh and a real denial of justice to workers, family people and small business owners. Not only are they harsh in their instant application but also in respect of some of them there is a continuing application. Who can afford to pay some $650 up front every time they try to get legal access to their children for the weekend? Who can afford to pay more in court fees than many low income earners earn in a month in order to sue their boss for unlawful dismissal? Which veterans or pensioners can afford to pay $4,000 just to prove that they are entitled to compensation or a pension?

We cannot look at these fees in isolation, because they are part of a broader attack by this government in this budget on access to justice. For all the pain in respect of these fees, you might have hoped, you might have thought, there would be some compensatory gain. But you do not find any additional resources put into our justice system to make it fairer and more equitable. These fees are a part of the single largest attack on access to justice that we have ever seen in this country. The measures in the budget attacking access to justice, altogether, will recoup for the government $320 million over four years from access to justice programs. That is twice the amount that the previous government's Justice Statement measures were calculated to cost.

Many of the significant reforms in that statement, many of the policy initiatives and many of the programs will be thrown away by this broad attack on access to justice in our system. Without thought, without care and without evaluation, it was chop, chop, chop all the way through, serial cutting, with no consideration—as we found out time and time again in the estimates process—of those important considerations of access to justice.

For those who feared Fightback, it is worth knowing that Fightback would have cut back only $100 million from access to justice programs over the same period. We are talking about over $300 million. If the National Commission of Audit's programs are implemented—and they are being assessed by the government now—then we are looking at a further $200 million of funding waiting on the chopping block for the Attorney and the government to wield an axe.

We have here, I think, an ideological attack on access to justice. Why is not access to justice a core commitment of the government? Why were these cuts made when, in doing so, the government indicated very strongly that access to the law and access to justice were not a core commitment? In respect of all of these, I think, in a sense, we can say that we are helpless in the Senate. We cannot make the government continue the funding in terms of mediation services, and so many other programs, and in terms of the community programs that were part of access to justice. We cannot force them to maintain the levels of legal aid which are critical for Australians in terms of their capacity to access the courts. We cannot stop so many of the cuts that will cause increasing delays in the Family Court and Federal Court systems. We cannot stop the betrayal of kids, for instance, in terms of the reduction of services from the Family Court, and so on.

There is one area where we can act and this is the one that is before us this evening, that is, we can tackle this particular issue. We can tackle it in a number of ways. We can tackle the government on their arguments. In terms of the estimates process, it became apparently clear that the government was committed to these increased recovery rates because it said that user pays, to a certain extent, should apply and we should try to link our cost recovery to the states.

The one principle that should not apply in the justice system is user pays. The words `user pays' came quite often from the officers who are trying to defend the government's moves here. But once again, it is the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia who has demonstrated why user pays is plain wrong in respect of this particular issue. In his speech to the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration, his Honour said of `user pays':

With respect, that profoundly mistakes the constitutional function of the judicial power of the State which, as I have said, is to apply the rule of law in resolving disputes and thereby preserving the peace, order and good government of society.

Justice should not be for sale. What the government is doing here is making it accessible to the highest bidder. Justice should not become a commodity for sale to the highest bidder. It is a public good and to that extent the principle of user pays should not be appropriate.

In terms of the other argument—that we have to link the fees here to schedules raised by the state courts—in a letter from the Law Council of Australia on 16 September, Michael Phelps set out the respective fees and charges in the state court systems. It is interesting to note that it only costs between $140 and $520 to commence an application in the state or territory supreme courts. It will cost $800 under this particular proposal to do so in the Federal Court for an individual and $1,600 for a company. Across the spectrum, when you look at the comparison of Federal Court and supreme court fees throughout Australia provided by the Law Council of Australia, you will find that this government's commitment to matching 30 per cent—which was the benchmark used—of state and territory fees is just plain wrong. It is a plain deception.

When you look at what it costs to commence an application in the Federal Court under these fees and charges raised by the federal government compared with existing fees and charges, you can see that their argument is a dishonest one. Of course, that is only in areas where you can make a comparison. You cannot make a comparison in respect of the High Court, the Family Court or the Native Title Tribunal. The states and territories do not have those sorts of jurisdictions. There are many inconsistencies and many injustices.

Another injustice is the injustice embodied in the principle here where individuals might be charged so much but companies will be charged double. There is no distinction drawn by the government between the mega‐corporations—like BHP—which are used to using litigation as a means to drive small players out of the markets, and so on, as opposed to the $2 family company owning the corner shop, the video store, the petrol station, or whatever. They all have to pay the same. Whether they are big, mega‐, international or national organisations, or the local family company, they will have to pay twice as much as an individual.

If there is a question about tax deductibility of legal fees, then fix the problem at the taxation system source and do not charge every corporation the same exorbitant fee. As far as we are concerned, we do not agree with the government's proposal because we see it as a grab for cash. When you look at the rhetoric of the government in terms of their justification, you find that rhetoric does not stand up. They have admitted, for instance, in the estimates process through their answers that, in raising all these fees and in levying all these fees, they did not once consider the impact that these fees might have on access to justice.

I have said for some time now that we have been prepared to be reasonable in terms of trying to accommodate a CPI based increase in the fees and to have this discussed by the parliament. But I must say that my patience has worn out. We have waited at least for two weeks from the last time that we deferred these disallowance resolutions. It was flagged two weeks ago that there would be negotiations between the parties to see whether we could come up with an alternative set of fees, a set of fees that may be acceptable to the Senate, or at least to some aspects of the Senate.

As I say, that was some two weeks ago. Nothing has been provided to us since. There was one contact last week where we were asked about our view. Even last night I expected that there might be some further communication from the Attorney‐General's office. In fact, we rang them this morning asking for more details for us to consider and nothing substantive has been put to us in terms of the government's negotiating capacity on this particular issue.

There might, in fact, be an afterthought; Senator Vanstone might in fact have some thoughts. We are now in a position where the Senate is to make a decision with no substantive concrete proposals before it as to what the government intends to do. We cannot take you on trust. We have had two weeks to get some indication from you. Having had that indication from Senator Vanstone last time, we moved very quickly into the estimates process that afternoon. I asked the officers what was on the table in terms of renegotiated fees and whether anything was being seriously looked at by the government and none of them knew anything about it. None of them knew that the scales were being reviewed. In fact, they assured us a number of times that no work was being done within the department to look at these sets of court fees to see how they could be modified to reduce their impact.

We have had no negotiations. We have had no information. I think it is a very poor situation that we find ourselves in now. After two weeks, when there had been quite an amount of time available, we are in a situation where the government still seeks to take over $70 million from poor families who have gone through a family court process—I must say that they are not so poor but, of course, they are poor afterwards—and over $30 million from others who might appear before the Federal Court.

It causes a problem because if there is an attempt to amend these regulations, it is now impossible to do so. Procedurally, under section 48B of the Acts Interpretation Act, the government cannot make these regulations while they are subject to the current motion or any other motion for disallowance. I think we are in a position where we cannot really amend on the run. I think we have to make a decision on the basis of what has been before us.

In the opposition, we are not prepared to have, at this particular stage, promises of vague amendments further down the track. One particular problem with that, of course, is that for every day that these regulations are not disallowed, many Australians are currently paying court fees at a level which they may not be paying in the end, and they should not be paying. In fact, many litigants are paying court fees for matters where, just a few weeks ago, they were not paying fees at all.

Typical divorces are still over $2,000—four times more than the $368 previously charged. Even if there is a cut, we have to compare that to the $368 previously charged. It is not good enough to come in at the last moment and suggest that maybe you might look at this down the track. In terms of the Federal Court, we are currently talking about a typical small business claim incurring some $12,500 in Federal Court fees. That is 10 times more than the amount currently charged. If you are going to come in with a last minute offer, Senator Vanstone, it is going to have to be somewhere close to that $1,000 rather than to the $12,000.

There are 20 different fee increases imposed in the Federal Court by these regulations. We would not entertain any reduction unless it went to the whole spectrum, unless it went to the AAT, the national Native Title Tribunal and the High Court. In essence, we are talking about a very drastic increase in fees and charges here and an increase which is going to rip the money out of those who probably cannot afford it.

You have argued in the estimates process that there is an exemption clause but, looking at that exemption clause, it was pretty clear from reading the legislation that, unless you are a legal aid recipient, a pensioner or concession card holder or a person who is described in the legislation as a person who, because of their financial circumstances would suffer hardship if the fees were imposed—and hardship has been interpreted, on my understanding, as meaning someone who is very close to being a legal aid recipient or a pensioner or concession card holder—then a general comment from the minister saying, `Well, we are going to broaden this' is really not good enough. It is the guidelines that need fixing, and they need fixing to ensure that the hardship provision means more than being closely linked to legal aid recipients and pensioners and concession card holders.

As I say, the hardship test, as it currently operates, basically ameliorates what could otherwise be a very strict test and it does not provide a suitable avenue for access to justice for the vast majority of low, lower and middle income earners. That is the broad spectrum but I would also like to finish on a particular area, and that is the area of the workplace industrial relations cases, and particularly unfair dismissal.

I have received recently a letter from the New South Wales Young Lawyers, dated 4 October. They have asked me and the opposition to support their submission to the Attorney-General to revoke these fees. It is interesting to go to some of the issues they raise. They raise, for instance, the question of industrial law matters. They say:

BREAK.PARA: The new fees will require an individual applicant to pay $800 to lodge the application, $1,000 to set a matter down for hearing and $550 per hearing day. A company or trade union would have to pay fees of double those amounts. There will be additional fees for issuing subpoenas, obtaining transcripts, lodging notices of motion and other standard procedures. The absolute minimum fee for an individual applicant would be $2350 and for a company or a union $5700. Many matters would incur fees 50% to 100% higher than those amounts.

Applications for matters of law to be referred or appealed to the Court from the Commission can be made by employer representatives or unions. Under the proposed new fees they would now have to pay an application fee of $1600, a setting down fee of $2000 and a daily hearing fee of $1100. This is a significant departure from the tradition of industrial matters being conducted for minimal cost. Since there is effectively no power to award costs the applicant will have to bear those costs even if successful.

So you have here a significant departure from established practice in industrial law—not just an increase but a significant departure. In respect of unfair dismissals, they say that that is a matter of particular concern to them. As they say:

While the Court fees will be waived for those eligible for Legal Aid and on other limited grounds, very few persons who had only just lost full time employment would qualify on those grounds. They would have to make a difficult decision to pay an $800 application fee, and face the prospect of paying a $1000 setting down fee and $550 per day in hearing fees at a time when they do not know whether they will obtain employment again in the foreseeable future. This would discourage many deserving claimants from making a claim.
They go on to say:

The claimants would also be advised that they would be very unlikely to get back those costs even if successful, under the essentially `no cost' jurisdiction. Further, given the limits on compensation payable and the usual compensation awards in the jurisdiction, they would be advised that the likely result may not warrant the cost involved in bringing proceedings.
What is really interesting is their reference to the AIRC annual report for 1994-95. The letter states:

. . . more than half of all awards for compensation payments for unfair dismissals were $6000 or less. I understand the soon to be released Annual Report for the 1995/96 year will show an almost identical result. The 1995/96 report will also show that 24% of compensation awards were for less than $3000. That report will also state that in about a third of unfair dismissal cases the hearing took more than one day.

Based on those statistics, an applicant, who would have to pay a minimum of $2350 for a one day hearing and a minimum of $2900 for a two day hearing, would get an average order of compensation of $6000, and 24% would get less than $3000. These figures show that once the fees are introduced many claimants would find they were financially not much better off—

That is in terms of running cases. In fact, they would be worse off. They would be deterred from running the sorts of cases that are so critical in terms of unfair dismissal. The letter goes on. It is a rather useful letter because it does make the point that these sorts of fees would also hinder early resolution of claims. One does not need too much of an imagination to realise that employers would recognise that litigants would find it difficult to pay the fees and serious offers to settle would be rare in coming forward.

There are a host of our industrial relations matters, but what we are talking about here is a new precedent in industrial law. It is particularly important for instance in unfair dismissal, where a claim that a dismissal was harsh, unjust or unreasonable would go to the AIRC for determination. But if the claim is on other grounds, such as on the ground of race, sex or religion, it would be heard initially in the Federal Court where an applicant would have to pay, from the start, additional fees.

What we have here before us today is consideration by this parliament of the one critical issue in terms of access to justice that we can have a say in. As I said earlier, there is a broad attack here. In relation to community legal centres and the justice statement, it has been dismembered—item by item, part by part—taking $320 million out of the process and replacing it with just a small handful of dollars in terms of one aspect of family support, though at the same time cutting apart many other programs in the family support area.

If we in the Senate are concerned about access to justice, if we are concerned about Australians feeling as though they have rights that they can pursue in our democracy, if we are concerned about the government not using this mechanism as a way to rip the guts out of access to our court system, then I think we have no choice but to disallow these regulations to increase court fees and charges.

I would like to have been in a position where I could have said, `Well, we have had some fruitful negotiations.' But, as I say, we made our starting position clear to the government, which was CPI based. We raised our concerns through the AAT in terms of Family Court, in terms of another industrial court and some other critical areas. Though there have been suggestions that maybe the government is looking at negotiating, the officials did not know that at the start. We have seen nothing today.

With a commitment to ensuring that people are not denied access, with a commitment to ensuring that the weakest in our society do not get hit by a levy of over $70 million on those who have to resort to using the family law system, we urge the Senate to maintain a very basic principle, a principle that means that access to justice is a right and not a privilege, that access to justice is not just another non-core commitment. It is very much a fundamental right of access in our democratic society. As I say, for these reasons we on the opposition side are very keen to ensure these regulations are disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In commencing, can I say that, if the Labor Party in its 13 years in government had never come into this place and sought to put up fees for courts and tribunals, what Senator Bolkus had to say might ring as being something he genuinely believed and had always practised himself. Since that is not the case, what he said today stands in stark contrast to Labor's record. I leave that to others to judge in that respect.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bolkus has made a point which has highlighted the ineptitude of the opposition in this respect. That is, he would have liked to have had some sensible negotiations. The two weeks have past and no offers have been made. What he has not spelt out to this chamber is that an approach was made and it was very clearly conveyed to the government that the opposition were not prepared to negotiate other than on the most unrealistic terms. That is, they put their peg down a very large distance from where the government wanted to be and indicated that that was that—we were either talking turkey at that level or we were out of the ballpark. So they in fact picked up their cards and walked away from the table.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think that's right.

—That is my understanding of it, and that is my description of it to this chamber. They did that without realising that in the end they would have to come back to the table and vote. They can do as they choose, but all the government can do is say, `We want to talk to you about this.' If we get the cold shoulder, if there is a clear indication that no real negotiations will take place, we will not waste our time talking with those parties anymore.

SPEECH.PARA: I make another point: Senator Bolkus at least once, if not on other occasions, indicated that this aspect—that is, the cost of courts and tribunals—is the one critical issue where we can have a say vis-a-vis the cost of justice. With the greatest respect, he is mistaken in that view. The fees in courts and tribunals have a role to play in the cost of justice. But, as Senator Cooney would know—and as I and other senators in this place who participated in the cost of justice inquiry know—the fees of courts and tribunals are but a part of the high cost of justice. They are not the sole indicator of it. They, like the cost of justice itself, move with time.

Clearly, the government wishes to oppose the disallowance motion as tabled by Senator Bolkus, but I do want to underline that the government—I in particular, along with other senators here—as I have indicated, has an abiding commitment to access to justice. We may go to that path by a different route than the previous government would have gone, but that does not mean we do not have that commitment.

We are also committed to ensuring those who make use of government services make a reasonable contribution to the cost of those services. On attaining office, we were faced with the legacy of the $8 billion black hole, the Beazley bankcard. This government was not afraid to take the decisions which had to be taken to deal with that legacy of our predecessors. We were not prepared to walk away from that black hole, as the previous government did. If we did walk away from it, we would be walking away from the weakest in our community, those who would benefit the most from having a government that has the strength of character to keep the fiscal matters in order.

One of the major commitments we made to the Australian people was a preparedness to make those hard decisions—they made the mess; we are prepared to fix it. We also said that, to the greatest extent possible, the pain would be shared across the whole community.

One area where it seemed clear that an adequate contribution was not being made was in relation to those who use the resources of the Commonwealth's courts and tribunals, many of whom stand to make significant gains. Indeed, until the major increases levied by our predecessors on 1 January this year—and I just wonder whether Senator Bolkus was aware of that—the level of cost recovery in Commonwealth courts and tribunals had fallen from a high of almost 21 per cent in 1989 under a Labor government to about 12 per cent in 1995.

For the information of honourable senators, I might point out that the cost of running the Commonwealth's courts and tribunals has risen from about $81 million in 1989 to over $230 million in the current financial year. These are massive increases in outlays. The cost of running the Family Court alone has risen to in excess of $100 million per annum. Perhaps as an indication of the cost of providing these services one need only look at the Federal Court, which has estimated that it costs in excess of $6,000 a day to keep a judge in a court.

To make some assessment of what was a reasonable contribution, the government looked at the average levels of cost recovery in the states and territories, and this averaged at about 30 per cent. We have taken decisions to move cost recovery across the Commonwealth system to that level. We continue to believe that this assessment was not unreasonable. The increases were spread across all the courts and tribunals, but they were not uniform in their impact. The government recognised, for example, that the special nature of the Family Court and the matters it deals with mean the same fee levels should not apply to the Family Court as to the Federal Court.

The changes we enacted meant that the level of cost recovery in the Family Court was estimated to rise to only 23 per cent whereas the increases in the Federal Court would raise cost recovery in that court to in excess of 50 per cent. So the differences between the Family Court and the Federal Court, as highlighted by Senator Bolkus, were in fact acknowledged in the lesser cost recovery being sought by the government in the Family Court.

We were concerned to ensure that the disadvantaged would not suffer because of these increases. At the same time as we moved to increase the level of cost recovery to its current estimates, we also moved to ensure that there was a uniform and fair system of exemptions and waivers in place to protect those who could not afford to pay. I remind the Senate that the Family Court now waives fees in approximately 40 per cent of the cases. Let us not pretend that every litigant in the Family Court is hard up. No-one pretends that, hopefully. Let us acknowledge that that court waives approximately 40 per cent. Clearly, those who cannot afford to pay, do not. This will continue to be the case.

Having set out the government's reasoning in bringing in these fees, we are aware of concerns that have been expressed about some of the impacts that the fees as currently imposed may have. While these concerns have not been expressed across the whole community, there have been issues raised by those in the legal profession and some in other groups that the government is concerned to deal with.

We do not believe that there needs to be significant movement from the fundamental structure of the fees as currently imposed. They have been designed so that those who use more of the system's resources should make the greatest contribution. The new daily fees for hearings in both the High Court and the Federal Court are examples of this approach. The introduction of a one-off hearing fee in the Family Court is another example.

As I indicated earlier, the government has considered the concerns that have been expressed. I would like to outline now for honourable senators the revised position that the government believes will take account of many of those concerns. Some concerns have been expressed in relation to the new fee regime in the Family Court. The government attempted to restrict the increases in that court and will make further efforts in that regard. The major reason behind the introduction of the fees for ancillary relief and the one-off fee for hearings was to ensure that those who use the greatest share of the court's resources—those seeking additional relief and those taking matters to a hearing—should make a larger contribution.

To partially offset this reduction, the government has decided to make a small additional increase to the fee for principal relief. The current fee will rise from $460 to $500. We propose to reduce the fee for ancillary relief from its current level of $250 to $150. Given the high level of waiver in the Family Court and the reduction in the fee, we believe that such a fee should be well within the reach of those who do not fall into the approximately 40 per cent of those whose fees are waived. In addition, the government will reduce the one-off hearing fee from $400 to $300 to reduce the impact of that fee.

TALK.START.PARA: —From $400 to what?

—To $300. In the Federal Court there will be a number of changes. Firstly, we will ensure that for unlawful dismissal matters, the fees payable in the Federal Court will be no higher than any payable for a similar matter in the Industrial Relations Commission under the new workplace relations legislation. There will be other reductions in fees in the Federal Court. The application fee for a non-corporate litigant will be reduced from $800 to $500 and from $1,600 to $1,200 for a corporate litigant. Applications to the court by creditors under the Bankruptcy Act will have the current fee reduced to the same level. The fees for lodging a cross-claim will be similarly reduced. I remind the Senate that there are no fees for the lodgment of a debtor's petition.

SPEECH.PARA: The daily hearing fees will be reduced from $550 and $1,100 to $400 and $800 respectively. In addition, the first day of hearing will not incur a fee but will be regarded as being included within the setting down fee. Fees for setting a matter down for appeal will be reduced from $1,500 and $3,000 to $1,000 and $2,000 respectively. All other fees will remain the same.

As I stated earlier, the government believes that this approach to the new fees in each of the courts and tribunals was reasonable and necessary in light of the difficult budgetary position that it found itself in. We have, however, made these significant concessions to deal with the express concerns. I point out that these concessions will significantly reduce the revenue expected.

The opposition has made much of its claims about the impact of the new fees. I could pick a number of significant holes in the figuring of Senator Bolkus in his worst case scenarios but, given the concessions made by the government, those scenarios will no longer even be a possibility.

I would like to make some comment on those who repeatedly say that the courts are only for the wealthy or the very poor. It is a criticism regularly echoed by those who offer no evidence to support their sweeping claims. Indeed, Chief Justice Gleeson of the New South Wales Supreme Court noted in 1992 that, despite the claims I mentioned earlier, the great majority of litigants in his court appeared to be neither very rich nor very poor. Such evidence as there is suggests that most individual litigants come from middle income groups.

Making reasonable charges for the use of Commonwealth courts and tribunals does not deny access to those who need to use the system for the resolution of their disputes. For some only a system which is free of any fees would be appropriate. But for the vast bulk of the community there is support for those who can afford to make a contribution being obliged to do so.

BREAK.PARA: I believe that with the changes I have announced the government has struck an appropriate balance between the need for proper contributions to be made by those who stand to make often significant gains from the Commonwealth's courts and tribunals and the need for litigants to make a reasonable contribution to the costs of running the system.

Dependent on the result of this debate, obviously, the government will move to make the necessary changes to the existing fees as from 1 September 1996, with the exception of the new fee for applications for divorce and nullity, which will operate as soon as the necessary changes to regulations can be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this motion to disallow what we see as an outrageous attempt to make the judiciary serve almost as a funding body for the executive. I take on board some of the comments made by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) and that there is an intention by the coalition government to perhaps rework these fees and charges in some way.

SPEECH.PARA: In light of the minister's suggestions, would it not be more appropriate for the government to withdraw the regulations that have been tabled and go back to the drawing board and work out a more appropriate and certainly fairer system of fees and charges? I am not convinced by the minister's offerings today to not support the disallowance before the chamber today. As I stated, the Australian Democrats will be supporting it.

We are also very glad that Senator Bolkus has decided to pursue this disallowance now. We have expressed concern that this debate did not take place as originally scheduled a couple of weeks ago, for the very reason that Senator Bolkus made so well: people are paying these fees as we speak.

These regulations are also part of a broader campaign, as Senator Bolkus has said. Coupled with legal aid cuts, this government is stretching the capacity of our legal system well beyond its limits. I believe it is obvious that any hampering of a citizen's access to their courts is a hampering of democracy.

BREAK.PARA: The judiciary exists as an essential and functioning arm of the government in this country. It is not a luxury that should be paid for. It is something that should be provided as a public utility. It should not be governed by privatisation, by user pays or undesirable corporatisation. I think that that is the direction in which the government is moving today with these regulations. It is, along with the legislature and the executive, part of our functioning and constitutional government.

The government has made no bones about the fact that it expects the judiciary to provide a greater cost recovery process. Once again, user pays. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join this debate just to clear up a few matters that have been raised. SPEECH.PARA: While it is, with respect, a convenient and emotional argument to latch onto, it is fundamentally flawed because, with what is before the Senate this evening, we are not dealing with a federal jurisdiction. BREAK.PARA: It does perturb me that I need to make a comment about the submission of the Law Council of Australia because I am, in fact, a member of it and the family law division. We are on the public record as saying that we do not oppose fee increases per se, just as long as they can be shown to be of general benefit.

When you look at the state jurisdictions having, in general, a cost recovery of approximately 30 per cent from the users, there are no cries from those on the opposite side that that is somehow inherently unjust. If it is not inherently unjust for the states to get a 30 per cent cost recovery from their judicial system, why is it that it is somehow inherently unjust for the Commonwealth to do so? That really is the argument that they have to put up in this place to try to convince those people who are genuinely thinking through the real issues on a logical basis—not those motivated by politics or cheap calling upon the emotions of domestic violence and other very unfortunate situations that we face within this community. We will be looking for the answer as to why it is not inherently unjust for the states but somehow it would be for the Commonwealth.

Let me say to those opposite that Senator Michael Tate, a former senator from my home state of Tasmania—who, I note, wants to enter the priesthood after having resigned his ambassadorial position to the Netherlands and the Holy See—said in the disallowance debates in 1992:

But, basically, the fees are being levied in order to assist the Federal Government to discharge its obligation to fund the system of justice, which we are obliged to do if our society is to remain one governed by the rule of law, and the contribution, running into some millions of dollars, certainly would be very helpful in that regard.
He then went on to say:

It may well be that $500 for a hearing in the Federal Court of Australia when one is paying thousands of dollars a day for counsel is not an extravagant amount at all. It could well be increased to help defray the costs which are otherwise borne by—
who did Senator Tate say?—
the ordinary taxpayers of Australia.

Those opposite try to be critical of us by saying that this is a grab by government for money. That is why they got this country into such a horrible economic mess. They only thought about government, and if the government did not raise the money, well, they put it on bankcard. The reality is that one day the chickens do come home to roost, and who has to foot the bill? It is going to be our fellow Australians—the taxpayers whom we are obliged to represent in this chamber.

I believe that we owe a duty to encourage people not to use the system and if they do avail themselves of a taxpayer funded system to make some, albeit very small, contribution to the overall facility that is thus provided by the ordinary taxpayers of Australia. Those who want to use the court system—and I accept that the vast majority of them don't but circumstances unfortunately make it such that they find themselves within that predicament—ought to make a contribution if they can afford it, and that is a very important caveat.

There are a lot of other matters that can be raised but what I think the salient point for those opposite to come to grips with is: why is it okay for states to get a 30 per cent cost recovery but somehow inherently not for the Commonwealth to do so? Why is it just for the ordinary Australian taxpayer, the battlers out there, to help fund and subsidise, especially in the Federal Court jurisdiction, those actions that have been taken by companies against each other and have reduced filing fees in that jurisdiction? It really does defy logic.

The other matter—and I think this is the most serious one—is in the family law jurisdiction where 40 per cent of those users accessing the Family Court already get all the fees waived. Are you going to tell us that more than 40 per cent of the community are somehow in a poverty trap that they cannot make a contribution? If that is your argument, it is a very real indictment on the mess that you left this country in on 2 March when the government of this country was handed over to us courtesy of the Australian electors.

Even those of us on this side who accuse you of economic mismanagement would never go as far as to say that virtually 50 per cent of the population was somehow put into a poverty trap by the previous 13 years of the Labor government.
