Unfortunately for the Senate, this report on the Notice Paper has an asterisk alongside it, which means that copies of this report are available only when this item is called on.

I think this is an important report because it is a report into the incidence and nature of workplace or enterprise bargaining in Australia over, effectively, the last financial year. What lies at the very heart of all of the debate that this nation has been engaged in on industrial relations changes is whether or not the existing act—the act introduced by the previous Labor government—is conducive to enterprise bargaining with the proper balance of protections for low paid workers and protections for workers in vulnerable positions in society and whether or not progress has been made under that act for enterprise bargaining in Australia.

I have not had a chance to read this report. I certainly think the Senate should take note of it. I intend to read it and speak in greater detail on its findings at a later time. But what can be said about it now is this: that, under the previous government, workplace bargaining or enterprise bargaining had been growing apace. The essential lie on which the government's legislation turns is that there had been slow movement in the industrial relations culture and that workplace bargaining had been ineffective.

What I think this report will show if it analyses the issues as fully as I believe the statistics demonstrate is that workplace bargaining in the public sector in Australia where the federal industrial relations act held sway had been particularly strong when compared with the conservatively governed states, where the look‐alike acts that this government now proposes to enact federally had applied. Workplace bargaining had been slow in those states by comparison. Indeed, the take‐up of workers in a fair system, the system that applied, had been greater than in a draconian system where unfairness ruled.

The second point is about the public sector. My understanding of the statistics in the public sector show a similar situation—that workers were readier to enter into enterprise bargains where they perceived the system to be fair compared with states where they have draconian look‐alike legislation to the federal legislation that is currently before the federal parliament. That says quite a lot.

This report is fundamental to any critical analysis of progress in industrial relations therefore because the central theme of workplace or enterprise bargaining is to engage workers and their employers in fair bargains in a manner which will create productivity, a greater return to shareholders, greater job security and a return to employees. That is, both sides of the management divide—if I can use what I think should be an archaic term but is coming back into more common usage now under this government—would see a common interest in growing the productivity of their enterprise so that they could share the benefits of that productivity growth.

PARA.BREAK: If it is done unfairly, one side will not play ball. If it is done fairly, both sides can and the economy benefits. This report—and we have just got it now; we have not had a chance to analyse it—should set out statistically the de tails of how you could compare the two systems. I think, therefore, it is quite an important report and should go to a lot of the debate this chamber is about to experience on this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —Considering that the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill is currently before the Senate—a bill which promotes individual agreements over enterprise bargaining—this is, as Senator Cook said, a most valuable report. It allows us the opportunity to compare the success of enterprise bargaining agreements conducted under part 6B of the act with the success, or otherwise, of individual agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: In my home state, Western Australia, the Court government has had individual agreements in workplaces for a number of years. At the Senate Economics References Committee, the commissioner of workplace agreements in that state provided a report on those workplace agreements.

Let us then compare these two reports, looking firstly at the annual report on enterprise bargaining, which was tabled today by the Department of Industrial Relations. The report says that enterprise bargaining has been adopted in a huge number of workplaces—from 39 per cent in those with 20 to 49 employees to 87 per cent in those with over 500 employees. Forty-six per cent of these are private sector workplaces; 54 per cent are public sector.

Enterprise bargaining has been taken up in a strong way amongst every sector of the economy—from 28 per cent in accommodation, cafes and restaurants to 81 per cent in electricity, gas and water. When one looks at the results of enterprise bargaining, it is no wonder so many companies have become involved. Sixty-two per cent of managers reported an increase in labour productivity after entering into an enterprise agreement, with no manager reporting a decrease. Interestingly, the same figure, 62 per cent, of enterprise agreements awarded wage rises based upon productivity increases. In 1995, the average raw wage increase per agreement was 8.3 per cent.

BREAK.PARA: In terms of profitability, 47 per cent of managers reported an increase in profits under an enterprise agreement and only 11 per cent reported a decrease. Furthermore, 50 per cent of managers reported an increase in the quality of their product, with none reporting a decrease. Forty-five per cent of managers said workers' skills had increased, with again none reporting a decrease. Skill development, as we all know, is an important contributor to productivity growth, and productivity growth is the major way—if not the only way—to raise real living standards over time.

Wages have also increased under enterprise bargaining. In 1995, 59 per cent of workers under an enterprise agreement reported an increase in weekly wages, with only two per cent reporting a decrease. Both employers and employees have reported their satisfaction with the enterprise bargaining system. Overall, 74 per cent of workplace managers said they were happy with the introduction of enterprise agreements. In terms of overall job satisfaction, 63 per cent of employees were satisfied after enterprise bargaining, and only 12 per cent were dissatisfied.

Enterprise bargaining, under the present system under the Commonwealth act, is achieving strong results—real win-win situations for employers and workers. The reason for this is simple: enterprise bargaining as we know it today promotes cooperation between employers and employees. It breaks down the old idea of divisiveness that unfortunately used to rule the Australian workplace.

Let us now turn to the report of the commissioner of workplace agreements to see how individual agreements under a Liberal government compare in Western Australia. According to his figures, in 83 per cent of cases, employees reported a wage rise, compared to 4.5 per cent who reported a decrease.

However, one must be very careful when looking simply at these end figures because of the methodology of the workplace agreements report. It does not arrive at this figure out of a solid statistical analysis, as the report of the Department of Industrial Relations does. Rather, this figure from Western Australia comes from the commissioner's staff asking the employee's opinion, before the agreement is registered, of whether they feel their wages are higher. There are no calculations of all the benefits of penalties, conditions and other entitlements. So, on the surface, a quick glance at the base rate may appear to indicate a rise. However, when all factors are considered by a true statistical analysis, the figure is much lower.

Wages are not the only indicator of whether or not a worker is better off. Over 50 per cent of workers reported an increase in hours worked—over twice as many as under the federal enterprise bargaining system. These longer working hours are particularly harsh when one considers that 40 per cent of the workers had their penalty rates for overtime eliminated, and nearly 55 per cent of workers lost their penalty rates for work within ordinary time. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Enterprise Bargaining in Australia 1995 annual report, which was prepared by the Department of Industrial Relations. This excellent report provides an important snapshot of how enterprise bargaining is developing in Australia. The comprehensiveness of this report, building on the base of the first one in 1994, is a credit to the researchers and ensures the report makes a valuable and timely contribution to the industrial relations debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Industrial Relations is required to produce this report annually because of section 170RC of the Industrial Relations Act. This section was the result of a successful Democrat amendment to the Brereton reform bill in 1993. It requires an annual report on the implementation of enterprise bargaining and its impacts on the employment conditions of employees, particularly women, part-time workers and migrants. This is the second report prepared by DIR and is based on a substantially bigger database than the first report.

The findings of the report provide both good news and bad news. The good news is that enterprise bargaining is spreading and that workers and managers are basically happy with it. The bad news is that the benefits of enterprise bargaining are not evenly spread and that women workers and workers in non‐unionised workplaces are losing out. I am quite concerned that the gap between male and female hourly earnings widened by 1.4 per cent in 1995, that women reported a larger increase in hours worked than did men, and that this trend was more evident in state employment agreements than in federal certified agreements. This highlights the need for detailed vetting of enterprise agreements to ensure that workers in a disadvantaged bargaining position—such as women—are not disadvantaged.

The fact that unionised workplaces were far more likely than non‐unionised workplaces to have enterprise agreements and that over 70 per cent of managers and 63 per cent of employees reported satisfaction with federal enterprise agreements shows that union involvement does not mean bargaining is stymied. It also shows that non‐unionists are failing to achieve the benefits of enterprise bargaining and highlights the need for the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 to encourage the effective operation of unions and for enterprise bargaining to be promoted in the non‐unionised workplace by both unions and the Employment Advocate.

Overall, the report shows that enterprise bargaining is gaining increasing acceptance in Australia and that federal certified agreements are a more productive, fair and satisfactory means of achieving agreements than state agreements such as those in Victoria and Western Australia. Indeed, the level of industrial disputation was higher under state employment agreements, where unions were often excluded, than under federal employment agreements where they were included.

PARA.BREAK: The report shows that far too many employers were still requiring employees to work harder rather than smarter and that this was affecting family life. There is a direct correlation between an increase in work intensity and stress and a decline in the ability to balance work and family issues. Closer attention needs to be paid to work and family issues in industrial relations to ensure that productivity is not at the expense of family life. The Democrats believe this report high lights the value of regular reporting on major reform issues and provides some strong messages which the government should take into account in modifying its workplace relations bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this legislative approach of regular reporting on major reform initiatives should be adopted in other areas where governments make huge and grandiose claims of massive benefits to test whether the benefits ever turn up or whether governments need to keep a watching brief on critical issues such as this. I note in passing that the workplace relations bill proposes to repeal section 170RC and to replace this very detailed and specific report with a more generalised report every three years. This is an approach the Democrats have serious concerns with. Governments must be prepared to have their reforms tested rigorously; this is an important part of the accountability process. I commend this report to the Senate.

I can say that the legislation currently in existence has facilitated agreements which I have been involved in relating to special conditions and special leave pertaining to family arrangements for workers in child‐care centres, for establishing landmark conditions for workers with disabilities working in the laundry industry and also for dealing generally with industrial prescriptions for manufacturing workers in a number of industries. So it is a very flexible system that we are operating under at the moment under the federal jurisdiction.

I cannot, however, say the same for the system which has been established by the Tasmanian Liberal government and which exists now, although it is subject to review by an inquiry of the Tasmanian House of Assembly at the moment. I would categorise that system as one which does not involve a true bargaining process and, indeed, the very simple tests to test that bargaining process do not establish the fairness of the system. The previous Tasmanian enterprise commissioner has expressed to the inquiry which was conducted by the Tasmanian House of Assembly his dissatisfaction with that legislation because he was not able to satisfy himself that the outcome of the agreements which he was required to register under the legislation was fair and equitable or that the bargaining process was proper and fair. That is a problem with agreements which are being struck under that type of legislation.

There are many similarities between the Tasmanian legislation as it now stands and the workplace relations bill which is currently being debated in the Senate. Consideration will have to be given to the actual effects of those types of measures that we can point to in states such as Tasmania and Western Australia when we have a look at the provisions in the workplace relations bill and the Senate determines how in practice the measures in the workplace relations bill will impact upon the workplace.

Enterprise bargaining is not a new term—it has gone on for all of this century, whether or not we have called it enterprise bargaining. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a few minutes of the Senate tonight to talk about the Iron Baron clean‐up. A little over a year ago a ship carrying $3.5 million worth of manganese hit Hebe Reef off the mouth of the Tamar River on the north coast of Tasmania. Initially, 300,000 litres of oil escaped from the fuel tanks and a further 25,000 were spilt into the sea as the hulk was lifted off the reef. An oil slick spread out over the reef and the surrounding coastline, extending eight kilometres up the Tamar River. Smaller traces of oil were spotted up to 15 kilometres upriver, 35 kilometres north‐east as far as Ninth Island and 30 kilometres west to Port Sorell.

BREAK.PARA: An immense clean‐up operation was commenced immediately, involving hundreds of people from many organisations working in close cooperation. The response to the oil spill was managed under the national plan to combat pollution of the sea by oil, led by the Port of Launceston Authority and joined by BHP's oil spill response group. Eight months after the accident, the Premier of Tasmania at the time, the Hon. Ray Groom, commended BHP for being `an outstanding corporate citizen'. He said:
They accepted at the outset full responsibility for the oil spill and took action to do this.

BHP had said from the beginning that it would not leave the job until the clean‐up was completed, and it certainly did not. Once the initial clean‐up was largely accomplished, BHP funded a $900,000 long‐term management and maintenance plan. Under this plan the short‐term and long‐term effects of the oil spill on the surrounding environment and the success of the measures taken to restore the environment have become the subject of intense and careful organised study.

Contracts were let to organisations based in Tasmania, including the University of Tasmania, the Queen Victoria Museum, the CSIRO Division of Oceanography and government departments. Professor Michael Cullen of Monash University was also commissioned to undertake research. The interim report from the long‐term impact assessment group was released a couple of months ago and brings to light some interesting results.

The results so far indicate that oil sediment at most locations has now returned to pre‐spill levels and the oil which contaminated rocks in the affected areas has weathered naturally and is disappearing. There appears to be no evidence now of contamination in fish and shellfish arising from the spill. At this stage, there appears to be no major impact on the seagrass beds in the Tamar River. Most of the initial impact of the oil spill on local beaches appears to have been short‐lived.

Plants and animals living in habitats along the shoreline were affected by the spill in the short term and the assessment of their recovery is still taking place. Preliminary data indicates there has been a definite impact on penguin populations, but the extent will only be known in the coming months as the penguins enter their new breeding cycle. The population of penguins will recover over time, according to Dr Simon Stanley from the marine environment branch of the Department of Primary Industries and Fisheries and chairman of the long‐term impact assessment group.

It is hard to calculate the size of the original penguin colonies. It is estimated that the region had about 140,000 birds before the oil spill from the Iron Baron. Immediately after the grounding, more than 2,000 birds were treated at Low Head, 300 of which died. A further 20,000 may have died at sea. But, even so, this is still very few considering the overall population.

At the Low Head rookery, last year's breeding cycle was lost, but the effect of the spill will not be known until this year's cycle is completed in September. No oil related effects have been detected on Hebe Reef or the other reefs in the area, although an area of approximately 170 metres by 20 metres was physically damaged by the ship. On the Hebe Reef itself there appears to be a slow recovery of animal and plant communities taking place and fish populations have returned to normal.

The quick and effective response by local volunteer groups working with specialists from BHP and the government has been the main factor in bringing about a remarkably quick environmental recovery. Other spin‐off benefits have been the detailed study which eventuated and which will be used for further research. The process used to implement the clean‐up and the recovery strategy is now a model for any future oil spills in Australian waters. Another benefit is that the environmental resources, which were not known before, have now been identified and are being monitored.

I want to take this opportunity to commend those who have been involved in the clean‐up operations and the very high standard of their expertise. The effective management of the disaster has limited the negative impact and brought considerable benefits. For example, on 2 February this year, the Low Head Pilot Station at the mouth of the River Tamar, which had been the sight of the wildlife rescue and treatment facility, was officially handed back to the Port of Launceston Authority, although it had been closed as a wildlife sanctuary back in September. The historic buildings were badly in need of restoration and, as part of its promise to return everything to its previous condition, BHP offered not only to return the grounds to their former standard but also to significantly upgrade the reserve. This project has now been completed and is attracting added interest from the tourists wanting to learn more about the Iron Baron incident.

The pilot station was built in 1835 and is surrounded by historical buildings which were in need of much work in order to realise their heritage potential. So heritage enhancement tasks undertaken by BHP between September and February included building of a cobblestone type road leading to the station, putting powerlines underground to improve the aesthetics of the area, installing heritage style lighting along the road and also landscaping and regrassing the entire area. BHP also created a display in consultation with the Port of Launceston Authority to be permanently set up inside their museum, which is in the main pilot station building. Some painting was also undertaken.

In conclusion, I want to thank the many volunteers who freely gave of their time and effort in the very difficult and time consuming task of rescuing and cleaning penguins and other birds, rehabilitating the coastline and undertaking other tasks, all of which have contributed to returning the coastline to its pre‐spill condition. I thank the Senate.

2. A Member should act in the public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take some moments of the Senate's time on the adjournment debate tonight to complete the few points I was making during presentation of documents an hour or so ago with respect to the royal commission inquiry into the Seaview accident. I was saying that the cost recovery policies of the Civil Aviation Authority, which was the regulatory authority of the time, had its origins in Labor government policies of the user pays doctrine of the mid-1980s, and that the application of that user pays doctrine reached its high point with the Civil Aviation Authority in the 1990-92 period, when it was known under the notorious title of the affordable safety doctrine. This is detailed to some degree in chapter 3 of the commissioner's report, from page 90 onwards.

SPEECH.PARA: The application of the cost recovery doctrine to aviation had its origins in an inquiry called the Bosch inquiry in the mid-1980s. The Bosch committee recommended that there were a lot of inefficiencies within the then Civil Aviation Authority and that they needed to be corrected first. When they were corrected, then it may be possible to go to 100 cost recovery from industry in a 10-year period. In actual fact, the CAA, with the support of the government, went to 108 per cent cost recovery inside a period of two years, and quite radical changes were made in the authority. As I said at the time, the baby was thrown out with the bathwater. The regulatory authority ceased to have the authority that it needed, or ceased to exercise properly the authority needed, to regulate aviation within Australia safely for the travelling public.

The Civil Aviation Authority made another mistake in its quest for commercialism. There is nothing more bizarre than a Public Service body when it tries to enter the commercial world. They do not have the skills, the experience or the system of reward and censure that the commercial world applies to its operators in industry. They made a mistaken definition of who the customer was. They saw the customer of the regulatory authority as the aviation industry itself—the airlines and the operators of aircraft for hire and reward and other operators of aircraft. The consequence of seeing the airlines and the industry as the customers, rather than the general public, who are the real customers of the industry, led to a policy of appeasement with all the flaws that flow from a policy of appeasement.

The flaws were manifested in the form of a degradation of surveillance on the industry. They invested this in the buzzwords of the time. They moved from what they called quality control—direct, hands-on surveillance of going around and inspecting companies, aircraft, aircrew and maintenance organisations and seeing for themselves what happened—which they said was now old fashioned, to what was called quality assurance, where they designated various people to discharge that responsibility subject to audit. In itself, that is not necessarily a bad thing, but it fell down because the Civil Aviation Authority failed to run adequate audit checks on the people that it gave delegated authority to.

PARA.BREAK: In the report of the commission there is a very appropriate quote from an in‐house journal of the Civil Aviation Authority at the time. One of the officers of the Civil Aviation Authority wrote in the journal that if Moses had believed in quality assurance rather than quality control he would not have come down from the mountain with the Ten Command ments; he would have come down with 10 guidelines. That is a rather tragically apt commentary on what happened here.

SPEECH.PARA: This report is absolute proof of the failure of the regulatory authority at the time and the operational doctrine that it followed. If this were all behind us, there would not be any point in my taking the time of the Senate tonight to talk about it.

I have been mixed up in the aviation industry for over 30 years as a pilot and for about 29 years as an aircraft owner. I have had an intimate involvement with the regulatory processes over a period of years from the time when it was the old Department of Civil Aviation through the move to the Department of Transport and back to the Civil Aviation Authority and now CASA. I have a very great fear that the situation today is no different from what it was two years ago when this dreadful and avoidable accident happened.

I cannot see any evidence at all that the quality of the regulatory authority has improved in any way at all. I do believe that the changing of the name of the authority has left the same practices in place. It is not the same people there. A lot of people carried on from the old CAA, but the same practices, the same mind‐set and the same ineffective surveillance are still there.

There is still a very great tendency to pick on the little rabbits of the industry, to pick on the people who do not fight back. Within my own personal experience, I have seen cases where people in the industry have been wrong, they have been quite culpable of breaching regulations, but they have fought back with ferocity and the regulatory authority has backed off. With a soft target, the authority will go in hard. They will take them to court and pursue that person relentlessly but, if someone fights back, the authority will not stand up and exercise its power responsibly and effectively. This report from the commissioner is testimony to that fact. I advise everyone to read it. It is a litany, an endless chain, of a lack of application of power at the correct time and in the correct way.

At the same time, the board in pursuing rabbits really exercises power very, very crudely. The ability to suspend licences of pilots summarily on the spot before any evidence is collected, and to do that with severe economic penalties on individuals who are operating in the industry, is without parallel in our society. No-one else can have their livelihood taken from them without due process being applied.

I come back to the point: I see no evidence at all that this authority has changed in any way at all. Its principal fault is a lack of professionalism in its ranks. The Senate has before it a bill to remodel the board of the Civil Aviation Authority. I think it is very important that that is done. While the members of the board at the present time are estimable people with worthy lives, ability and all the rest of it, very few of them have any knowledge of the industry at all.

This is a very complex industry. It does need people who have both an extensive exposure and knowledge of the industry and have been at it for a fair while. It does need as its chairman someone who is a professional airman or a professional aeronautical engineer. It is not a job for people who are motivated by good intentions or something like that. But, at the end of the day, the board really sets policy; it does not set the detail of what the regulatory authority does.

The real problem with cleaning up the Civil Aviation Authority—or CASA, as it is now known—lies not with the Chief Executive Officer but that line of managers below the Chief Executive Officer who, in a general sense, are not capable of discharging the duties they are required to perform. There has to be a change there, otherwise the authority will not improve. Sure, we need to revise the regulations because in many ways our aviation industry here is very over‐regulated compared with other countries. Those regulations, when they are revised, need to be applied correctly, fearlessly and responsibly.

We need to get people back into the Civil Aviation Authority, or the CASA, the way it was back in the days of the DCA, who know the industry intimately at all levels. We need to have a clear objective of not looking after the customer, but of looking after the public interest, the travelling public, the people who pay fares to be flown on either charter or regular public service flights. We need to look after those who send freight by aircraft and those who live under the flight paths of aircraft. That is the primary responsibility and it requires targeting and the setting of priorities with respect to surveillance.

I do believe we have to take the authority back in as a department of state. We as a parliament do need to be able to oversee it. I mention that because one of the former heads of the Civil Aviation Authority, Mr Baldwin, when all this nonsense was carried on in 1990‐92, absolutely refused to explain it to the parliament. He said he was the chief of a government business enterprise and he was not answerable to anyone in parliament. This is a matter that urgently needs addressing. The authority must be answerable to the parliament so that all of us can have oversight. (Time expired)
